TL;DR This game is f*cking awesome, double the fun if you got a controller and HOLY SH*T IT'S SO MUCH FUN WITH FRIENDS!Since I got a controller I was looking for that special game to play that would justify buying one, this is that game.I was trying to convince a group of friends to purchase the game with me so I would have someone to play it with for a while, I must point out that they all play almost exclusively FPS games and were repelled by the idea of playing an arcade or sonic game, yesterday they finally bought it and I swear after the first race they were all so excited and shouting over skype about how much fun they were having and we just played it all night long even though we had a workday coming we played like 20 rounds following each by saying "I swear this is the last round before bed".Pros:You can play this game with up to 10 friends!The controls are amazingly smooth and you got a variety of characters to choose from.Tons of ageless fun!Cons:Nopewould/10

content:
Posted: March 7
												It's the closest thing to playing Mario Kart on a PC and it has enough bells and whistles to make it an excellent game in its own right. SEGA has a rich history and they have transformed that into a heap of excellent stages. Level design is inspired, with many a stage transforming throughout the race - the final lap is often very different to the first lap. Performance on my PC was excellent. I played in at 4k @ 60 fps using a GTX980. Never experienced any slowdown. An easy recommend for anyone who enjoys cart racing games. I'd be shocked if anyone who loved Mario Kart didn't also have a heap of fun playing this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												3D racing games have generally been divided into two broad categories. First you have simulation racers, games that aim for “realism” with physics and car handling that could ostensibly make sense in our own world. Some appeal to the respected F1 aficionado, some exist as a cost-effective way for guys to pretend they have artificial access to the all the hot name-brand cars of feverish adolescent dreams. Which brings us to the other category of racing games: the arcade racer, or simply the ones that are fun: Mario Kart, F-Zero, Outrun, Burnout, and the Need For Speed series in its prime. Zip and zoom through colorful, futuristic fantasy courses, abuse fat plumbers and perpetually-90's cartoon animals with goofy weaponry, safely crash and power drift until the finish line. The brand of car you use to do so doesn’t matter. In fact, it doesn’t have to be a car at all as long as the action is beautiful.  Developed by Sumo Digital, Sonic & All-Stars Racing: Transformed is an arcade racer that captures the spirit of the genre, its twists and turns throughout the decades, while simultaneously paying homage to Sega's better days. It borrows concepts from its forebearers and manages to improve upon them or make the formula fresh again, against the odds. The A to B routine is thus: hold down accelerate, drift around corners, repeat for a set number of laps quicker than your opponent. SASRT aims to keep your hands and senses focused at every second, no cruise control. As the name of the game should imply, the courses and cars transform: land to air, air to sea, cars become boats and planes. Nintendo 64 classic Diddy Kong Racing attempted a land/air/sea dynamic, but races only allowed one vehicle and terrain at a time. SASRT will throw you from asphalt to water or sky at a brisk pace in any given race. The tracks themselves will often transform on the 2nd and 3rd laps, ensuring that you'll stay aware instead of falling into rigid muscle memory, lap after lap. Item pickups are lifted from the kart racing subgenre that Mario Kart pioneered, but their inclusion balances out the action rather than punishing skilled players. There are no items like the oft-dreaded blue shell from Mario Kart, no items that feel excessively unfair whenever they smack you from front or behind. With enough skill, damage can even be avoided altogether through perfectly executed evasive boosting. What sets this game apart from a mere whimsical kart racer is the sense of speed. Especially on the higher difficulty levels, SASRT approaches F-Zero GX levels of breakneck precision. The vehicles don’t control like silky smooth, marshmallowy sweet go-karts, but rather strange beasts that feel like they need to be wrangled in order to reach the finish line in a decent placing.  Boosting is key to winning against the sometimes brutal AI, a task that can be accomplished in a number of ways. Smart drifting is the most important tool, with each successful maneuver giving a varying amount of boost power. Sumo Digital was also responsible for the console and PC ports of Sega AM2's OutRun 2006 Coast 2 Coast, an arcade game renowned for its drift mechanics. After playing SASRT, it's apparent that Sumo has a keen understanding of that game's framework, the precarious task of coding lovely, frictive momentum into a racing game. They've even managed to keep the fast friction intact during the air race segments, a task I haven't seen accomplished by other games of this ilk (I’m looking at you, Banjo Pilot). Also borrowed from the all-important Mario Kart is the trick system. While later entries in that series allow for simple one-button tricks to be performed off of ramps for a small speed boost, SASRT designates four directional inputs on your second analog stick for accomplishing combos. You can perform backflips, forward flips, side somersaults however many times you think is smart before nailing (or screwing up) the landing. Though it’s not as complex as any trick-focused game like SSX, it’s another element to keep in mind while racing. Arcade racers thrive on a pick-up-and-play mentality and don’t need to have complex fighting game-like button combinations, but SASRT tries to keep more advanced players on their toes. You can even do tricks off the waves and crests in the water, encouraging you to always keep your eyes on the road (whatever form it takes) for ways to get ahead of the competition.Unfortunately, unlike the gameplay itself, not as much holistic attention was paid to the game’s presentation. The game comes close to being a celebration of Sega, a fanboy’s greatest hits stocking stuffer. Yes, there's an unlockable racer that transforms into Dreamcast controller, a vehicle that belches the console’s signature disc-reading grinding noises and home menu bloops. Yes, the first track in the game features a remix medley featuring “You Can Do Anything” from Sonic CD. The song that plays when Beat from Jet Set Radio gets his All-Star power-up is an awesome jam, too. All of these flourishes are nearly negated by the inclusion of NASCAR superstar Danica Patrick. And that box-office neanderthal Wreck-It-Ralph.  And the obligatory PC-only Team Fortress 2 character and some historical-esque characters from the Total War and Company of Heroes series. Once again, I have to compare Sega to its closest analogue as a publisher and a creative brand, its once friendly rival that has survived all these years as Shenmue 3 dies endlessly and Sonic’s arms are dyed blue. Nintendo’s biggest games often have a fetish-like focus on their own history,with constant throwbacks and an internal logic at play within their respective game worlds. The Mario Kart games feel like they exist in a unified world despite all the wildly different locales. Look up a picture of the Lakitu creatures: it makes logical sense that they’re the unionized workers controlling the cameras, starting green lights, fishing out racers from bottomless ditches and lakes. To be fair, SASRT does have the disadvantage (or advantage, depending) of drawing characters from various series under the Sega brand. Nintendo’s Smash Bros series does a similar feat, though the inclusion of non-Nintendo characters and worlds from Mega Man and Sonic makes some kind of sense: there’s a similar demographic of fans and a rich intertwined history behind those iconic characters. Including Danica Patrick in a game like this is as awkward, weird and incongruous as the time Sonic The Hedgehog was forced to kiss a CGI human woman back in 2006.It’s a good thing it doesn’t matter who or what you race as in an arcade racer. If Disney putting Wreck-It-Ralph in this game helped support all the people who crafted this excellent feeling Sega game, then let Mickey Mouse’s warm corporate fingers embrace all of Sega. Life support is an expensive and dear thing, keep that in mind.Sonic & All-Stars Racing: Transformed is more than a Mario Kart clone or a “Mario Kart Killer,” more than a praiseworthy attempt by Sega to “do what Nintendon’t”. For all its blemishes, this is the best game released by Sega in years. Yes, there are many other excellent titles that have proudly worn that old blue and white logo during this past generation. But when I say Sega, I’m talking about the real Sega, a brand that had so many forward-thinking yet simple ideas that exploded into the arcades and our living rooms alike, ones far too unique to make good business sense. A Sega that was more than a corporate publishing vessel for PC strategy games and deceptive blue-hedgehog-hamster-wheels on your mobile phone. A Sega that entranced fans and made its name seem like a colorfully exotic word, a gift from the beyond, rather than the boring truth: a portmanteau of “Service Games.” Just one more quarter in the slot, one more clearance Dreamcast sold for $99, and maybe we could all have a good time for just another year.

Posted: July 25, 2013
												Sonic All-Stars RACING TRANSFORMED® is a game you would rightfully assume is about going fast, then going faster. In reality it's a harsh lesson about how the world works and what to expect in the competitive job market. In your quest to go fast and feel the sunshine you will quickly find out others too want to go fast, in fact they want to go faster than you. The problem is if someone is going fast more than you are going fast then you are in fact not going fast so only one person can actually go fast. This creates a situation where much like the race for jobs and the corporate ladder, when you have everyone trying to go fast no one in fact goes fast since you constantly impede each other from going fast.Which is symbolism for the nuclear arms race.I give this game 10 WHY ARE THERE BEES OH GOD THERE'S MORE BEES WHO EVEN MAKES ALL THESE BEES OH GOD THEY'RE ALL OVER MY CAR AND IN MY PANTS AND OH GOD MY EYE WHY GOD WHY Out Of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												You know how Nintendo keeps making Mario Karts, and how they always add something new to the mix, but it never quite overhauls the base principles? Well, Sonic Racing Transformed does. I bet SEGA took every single complaint ever made about Mario Kart, and worked it into an extremely well made and competative kart racer. The AI isn't made of super rubber, there are no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t blue shells, the catch-up item is fair, the selection of characters is diverse and entertaining, the transforming mechanic really shakes up the pace and the tracks are a real step up from the last installment. It also feels more like a SEGA all stars homage then just Sonic & co. with some other peeps. You're really in the SEGA universe thanks to the wide representation of series, the music and the online works. That last isn' really SEGA, but contrary to Mario Kart's online, its a step upwards. I'm fueling a 90s console war debate here and I'm loving it. Great game.

												Got this game for my kids and I'm having as much fun as they are.  This is Mario Kart on some serious steroids.   Pure arcade racing in some pretty imaginative environments. content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												This game was unexpected. I tried a demo from the previous version on the PS3 and it was great to play with friends but this..this is just AWESOME!As a long time Mario Kart player this ain't a pure clone, it's a superior experience. You have land kart transforming into air and water machines on every track, you have super funny "Capture The Chao" games or Battle Arena ones, there's even a Boost Race mode.The characters are well designed and there's a lot of interesting cameos(Wreck-it Ralph and Team Fortress among others), the tracks are amazing and the graphic and light effects are just awesome.I was expecting a bad console porting too but the game just feels fluid and great.Sure, it's better played with a gamepad but once you learn the basic controls even playing with the default keyboard layout feels right and you never have the feeling you're not in control of your kart.Definitely a big big surprise I'd reccomend to everyone, playing with 2 other friends already makes it 100 times more awesome!The single player is good too and it's necessary to unlock tracks(which you unlock anyway if you play with a friend who owns it) and characters but I'd still reccomend to get it if you have friends to play with.VOTE: 8.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2013
												This is possibly the best Mario Kart style racing game yet. It's absolutely gorgeous, has excellent track design, the transforming vehicle gimmick works very well, lots of variety in tracks and racers, unlockable customization options for each racer, and it's just a hell of a lot of fun.Unlike the first All-Stars racing game, this one does have the full set of online modes an options on the PC version. In face, it's an incredibly solid PC port. I wonder if the three racers added from PC gaming franchises are there to reassure us that Sega isn't short-changing the PC versions of their games anymore.If you've ever enjoyed any kart-style racing game, I can recommend this one without hesitation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												As a big fan of the SMK (Mario Kart) series and hearing a lot about this game, I finally decided to give it a go and dropped some money on it.  I chose the PC version over the Wii U version (my second choice - and may still pick it up for Wii U) because of the larger character roster and DLC.  Note that I haven't picked up any DLC - yet.Difficulty notwithstanding (I feel the game is pretty easy, even on hard), the game is a lot of fun!  Unlike Mario Kart, there are very few OP weapons, and there are no weapons that will hunt you mercilessly if you're in 1st.  As a matter of fact, it's possible to evade almost all weapons thrown or shot at you, given enough skill, which is a plus for me.  The stages are well-designed, the big point-earner being that all the stages change from lap to lap, sometimes significantly.  The stage changes result in your character changing the vehicle they're racing in on-the-fly, which brings us to a more contentious part of the game: flying and motorboating.  Although I find that a higher Handling for your character results in a more controlled flight (I personally love flying in this game, though many weapons become harder to use - there is a bit of auto-aiming provided, though), I don't get the same kind of responsive control when on the water.  Unfortunately, I feel the water physics is pretty mediocre at best, and this especially rings true on certain stages where you're on the water for most of the race.  Sega definitely invested more in flying mechanics and racing on the ground.Finally, the character selection is very diverse, with famous Sega mascots all appearing, some old-school characters that haven't seen the light of day in a long time (looking at you, Alex Kidd!), and for the PC version, PC-specific characters, such as the Spy/Pyro/Heavy trio from Team Fortress 2.  The only character that I felt was kinda just forced in was Wreck-It Ralph, who isn't a Sega character and doesn't have any games on the PC.Overall, I'm really enjoying this game, though I feel it is a bit on the easy side.  Is it worth the 20 bucks?  I'd say so, though if you find it on sale, scoop it up immediately!

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
Product received for free
												To be honest, I was gifted this game by a friend so I didn't spend any money on it, however... It is worth the price that it is now.The game, although filled to the brim with unrecognizable characters besides Sonic and his Friends, TF2, and Wreck-It Ralph (For me), is still fun whether or not you know who the characters are. Each character has different stats and different animations and it's always fun to try out new characters. You can also go through blue rings in order to transform and your vehicle can either transform from a car to a boat to a plane whenever you pass through them, hence why this is "Transformed". It's fun and kind of reminds me of Mario Kart except each stage feels unique and different, including several stages from different Sega games such as Sonic The Hedgehog, Golden-Axe, etc.DLC is pretty cool too, the best one would have to be the Metal Sonic DLC for me because Metal Sonic has to be one of my favorite villains in Sonic The Hedgehog. It includes Metal Sonic of course and a stage called Outrun which is pretty nice. Did I mention it's the cheapest DLC of the 3? ;)Yogscast would probably have to be my least favorite one, I know it's for charity, but if they really wanted to use an internet celebrity, I think they should have done the Angry Video Game Nerd, would have really liked to see some F-Bombs drop on Sonic while he's racing against him.All in all 9/10 as a racing game for me, this is probably one of the best celebrity racing games I've ever played, although the celebrities are not very recognizable if you haven't played their respected games, you can still appreciate the gameplay and who knows, it could even get you interested in their games and you could find a new one to play :P

It's installed and I played 1-2 hours (don't get me wrong, I love the new GTA V and I think it's pure awesomeness... but ... but this little...) and in Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed I already have 9.2 hours of gameplay (single-player & multi-player). THIS LITTLE GAME HAS THE POWER TO PUT GTA V ON HOLD - for that and not only for that I'll give it a 10/10 for the best arcade-racing game of 2013. GORGEOUS!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												+ Very polished racing game+ Known characters and scenarios from famous SEGA games (and a few characters from games not developed or published by them)+ Great amount of content+ Tracks feel fresh and well elaborated+ Gorgeous graphics+ Smooth and intuitive gameplay+ Arguably, the DLCs seem fair considering how much content the base game offers+ Not as quirky as Mario Kart, but still pretty good (and the only option on PC that comes pretty close to MK)+ Engaging multiplayer (still active after three-four years)- Sounds can be too loud even with the volumes down by 30 levels- The narrator speaks way too much in the menus (arguably in the races as well)- Interface is too simplistic, so it might feel a bit lacking for some players- Could have more characters and tracks from other renowned SEGA franchises such as Phantasy Star, Bayonetta and Golden AxeVerdict: The first Sonic game I played was on the Genesis and it wasn't much. Then I played something someone (or SEGA themselves) released for browsers more than a decade ago. I didn't care for Sonic up until I started playing Phantasy Star Online 2. The fact that SEGA refuses to release PSO2 in the West to instead give us more Sonic games that no one asked for made me get a grudge with it, but then there's the PSO2 anniversary lobby and EQs with songs from Dreamcast Sonic games. If you're reading this and you've played PSO2 around that time, you probably know why this is a reason for me not to like Sonic.Anyway,I still don't like Sonic as a character, but I certainly see it differently as a franchise. I tried ASRT on Android and was very disappointed with it, but I've always had my eyes on the Steam release cos I knew I'd like it better if I played with a controller. It went beyond my expectations, proving to be a very polished racing game with everything I could ask of it and more!

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Cause Driving A Kart Wasnt Hard Enough As Is...Game Mechanics - 2/2Story-line - 1/2Graphics - 1.5/2Soundtrack - 1.5/2Replay Value - 2/2 Total Score - 8/10So here I find myself writing up another Friday review for some faithful, interested gamer out there and I wouldn't have it any other way. With that said welcome to another Friday video game review here on In The Mind Of My Mind with your friendly neighborhood gamer Zalgo_Cometh. I been waiting and wanting to get myself a copy of this game from I heard they were making a part two after all the success the first game received. We reviewed Sonic & Sega All Star Racing two years ago and now its back for round two.Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a racing video game developed by Sumo Digital and published by Sega. Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is the sequel to Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing, the fourth installment in the Sega Superstars series, and the eighth racing game in the Sonic the Hedgehog series. Do you think the sequel lives up to its predecessor  Let's find out on today's exciting episode of Dragonball Z..........wait wrong show; I mean on today's blog review. Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a mascot-based racing game in which players race against each other using characters from various Sega franchises, although it features many new mechanics and improvements from the last game. The most obvious is that, at certain points in a race, vehicles can alternate between car, boat and plane modes. The car mode handles similarly to the previous game, in which players can earn boost by drifting around corners or performing tricks whilst in the air. Boat mode features true boating physics, requiring players to consider their vehicle's turbulence. They may also be affected by waves made in the water, some of which can be used to leap into the air and perform stunts. Plane mode, the fastest of the three forms, gives players the freedom to move both vertically and horizontally. Like the other modes, players can 'air-drift' around corners to earn boost and can also perform rolls to quickly adjust their position, earning boost for narrowly dodging obstacles. Players alternate between these modes by driving through blue transformation gates. Certain tracks in the game terraform as players proceed through them, offering different play-styles between each lap.What’s Good:Game-play: I must say Sega really listened to the fans and went all out to improve this series and I certainly see it as a worthy competitor to the Mario Kart franchise. With a wide variety of tweaks and subtle game-play enhancements this game certainly has quite the competitive edge to offer. When playing this game it certainly feels like a true race that is determined mostly by skill and not just sheer luck. From the changing track layout to the varying modes of transportation to the subtle handling differences in the varying modes of transport; Sega has offered up a selection of any and everything imaginable to affect a racing game of this wacky and nostalgic nature. Add into that the wide character roster of old and new faces alike and you simply cannot go wrong.Replay Value:With such a wide cast of characters to explore how could you not have replay value? Add to that a variety of race modes and tracks for both single player and multi-player enjoyment and you will be begging for a break. Sega went even further and gave us a leveling system for each character and different car mods to unlock and explore for each of your favorite characters. This is what you call some serious replay value.What’s Bad:Story-line: WHERE IS THE STORY LINE? WHY DO I NOT KNOW HOW THESE CHARACTERS ALL GOT TO THIS DIMENSION? WHAT ARE THEY EVEN RACING FOR? Hell the most important question of them all is why Sonic is even driving a car when he is obviously the fastest participant of this whole racing game? Trolling aside it would have been nice to have a dedicated story-line to help add value to the game and develop more interest in the varying characters. What Should Have Been Added:Pretty much like I said that only main thing I would have wanted to see was a properly fleshed out story to help solidify this game.Final Thoughts:I am definitely glad to see the success this game is receiving and hope that Sega and Sumo Digital continue to make this a worthy addition to the kart racing game genre. especially since its the only kart racing game I know of that has a version for PC which is way easier to get people to play on locally than with a handheld or a console. I hope to see continued variety of character inclusion from the illustrious Sega collection of characters they have at their disposal.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is possibly the best Kart racer I have ever played.  Having grown up as a SEGA fanboy, this is the SEGA answer to Mario Kart that I always wanted and the PC version definitely gives Mario Kart 8 a run for its money! It's also a great livingroom PC/HTPC game, as it supports up to 4 players on a single screen (local splitscreen.)The tracks are varied and well designed, with plenty of shortcuts and bonuses which reward skilled players.  Being a huge SEGA fan from back in the day, I really appreciated the call-backs and themes the levels offered (Golden Axe, Shinobi, Skies of Arcadia, and more!)As far as difficulty is concerned, this game is no cakewalk.  There is a learning curve involved in teaching yourself how to drift, how to boost, and how to stack boosts in order to be competitive, but the game greatly rewards you for building your skill.  Beware: The A.I is absolutely cutthroat and they won't show you any mercy while you're still getting used to things.  While at first they seem to be absolutely unfair, they can be overcome with practice and skill as well as knowledge of the track.  They do not rubber-band to the player like Mario Kart's opponents do in older entries.  There are items which you can use to attack/sabotage other drivers just like in Mario Kart, however they play less of an important role in SASRT, as you will not find yourself getting item-spammed at inopportune times if you're good enough to get ahead of the pack.The tracks themselves can change lap-to-lap and new situations may require a new type of vehicle.  That's where the "transformed" part of the game's name comes in.  Each vehicle is capable of transforming from a car to a boat to a plane and back again, depending on the level's terrain.  The transformations are automatic (so you don't have to worry about having the wrong vehicle type at the wrong time) and they add a great variety to the overall gameplay.  There is a learning curve involved in learning the different handling of each vehicle type (especially the planes), but they are not difficult to get a hang of.Each character has unique stats and abilities and they can be leveled up through racing and completing events/challenges.  When leveling up, you can unlock 'mods' which drastically alter your character's stats and can be helpful on certain courses (for example, the handling mod will boost cart handling and can help on an icy stage with lots of turns.)Another huge advantage that this game has over Mario Kart is its Single Player campaign.  While Mario Kart only really offers a Grand Prix and Time Trial mode for its single player experience, SASRT offers both of those plus a "World Tour" mode in which players must complete a wide variety of events (races, drift challenges, boost challenges, combat race challenges, etc) to earn stars which can be used to unlock additional characters as well as stat/kart upgrades.  If you want, you can even play local multiplayer in World Tour mode (up to 4 players) and everyone can take on the challenge simultaneously. I found that I got a good 30 hours of gameplay out of World Tour so far and I haven't even 100% finished it yet; there's lots of content to be had!I highly recommend this game to any fans of racers, Sonic, and SEGA franchises of old.  You won't find a better Mario Kart alternative on PC (short of emulation.)

												This game is great fun and probably the most fun I've had with a kart racer since Mario Kart DS. There's  a nice assortment of characters (maybe too much from Sonic), a lot of levels which are pretty much all fantastic (with mirror versions), and the controls are tight. While it's a kart racer, skill plays a large factor and items can only do so much when going up against skilled opponents. My main gripe is that there are some issues which can occur with collision on the tracks, specifically with regards to skyboxes, but these hardly detract from the overall experience and occur infrequently. The graphics are nice, the music is great, and the game just plays very well. This is a great game and I recommend this to anyone interested in racing games or with a love for Sega.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												So, when Sonic & All-Stars Racing first came out, everyone pretty much just passed it off as a Mario Kart clone that would never quite make it. But, with this installment, it blows that idea out of the water. This is better than Mario Kart. While it has less in the way of more well-known characters and wacky items, it has its own charm with nostalgic favourites like Beat and Ulala from Sega's classics; alongside representatives from their newer IPs; all the while revelling in cheesy dialogue from them all and a range of dynamic, stunning tracks to race around. It doesn't try to be something so much greater than Mario Kart or similar family racing games; but pulls it off anyway - it's just wild and fun, The fact that rubber-banding effects are really lessened in this game is particularly welcome, although it still has its own type - the All-Star moves; although they are fun in their own way.All in all, highly recommended for anyone who's getting a bit old for Mario Kart or just wants to try something new.

												I guess i should start with being honest, i am bias towards racing games as they made up a great portion of my childhood gaming experience, having grown up with games like: Crash Team Racing, Gran Turismo, Mario Kart, Ridge Racer, Toy Story Racing, and so on; although often the crucible of frustration and anger but still very dear to me. After playing 'Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed' i can wholeheartedly say without a doubt that this racing games takes the cake as the most enjoyable for me. Naturally this is my own, personal opinion and i'm aware that others will disagree, but i think that this particular racing game is just brilliant; great characters, courses, stunts, boosts, challenges, soundtrack, online playability, you name it and it's here. Any racing lover needs to try this game, you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												It had been a long time since I last played a good old racing kart game, and suddenly this game appeared before my eyes on Steam. By looking at some videos of the gameplay and reading some of the positive reviews I decided to give it a shot, and boy did I become a fan real quick! I have always liked kart games like these for their beautiful colors, goofy characters and creative weapons and this game nails those spots right on!With beloved characters from the SEGA universe and some newcomers, this game offers a real nice variation of vehicles along with awesome and unique All-Star moves to go along with which lets you choose your way to devastate the track when you're having a bad day and watch you fly right past the competition in an awesome spectacle, may it be by the usage of rockets, soundwaves or bananas. The creative weapons are both amusing and rediculous and makes the races go completely out of control which is one of the charms of kart games like these. You can also find the usual powerups which lets you boost up to higher speeds or block incoming attacks, but with all the crazy weapons and powerups aside, this game can really offer you a test of racing skill to see if you got what it takes to go even faster by using risky air-stunts and powerful drift-boosts which, altough makes the game a little more difficult, also makes the game more thrilling and exciting and overall more fun. The race tracks are, what you would expect, tracks based on several of the SEGA character's original titles which definitely is a must for party games like these, and putting the "Transformed" in this game's title is the fact that in most of the stages there is a transition to race by both boat and plane during the race which puts more variety and challenge into the game.So if you're a fan of racing games with elements of driving by car, boat and plane as well as neat combos you can pull off, or even if you're just a fan of Sonic and his friends I truly recommend and tell you that this game is for you!

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game is the Mario Kart 8 equivalent for PC! Characters are not as memorable, but functionally it's just so much fun. Split-screen and online modes are all available, and it works perfectly on both keyboard and controller. Maps are extremely lively, there's so much happening, and gameplay is constantly spiced up throughout the laps with cars, boats and flying machines. Pickups are easily recognizable after even the first race, making it very easy to just jump into if you've enjoyed Mario Kart in the past (on SNES, N64, GameCube, Wii etc).It's a living-room blast. I highly recommend this title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I picked up Sonic & All-Stars Racing: Transformed (SASRT) during the 2015 Steam Summer Sales almost at random out of boredom, thinking it probably was the poor man's Mario Kart.  Boy was I absolutely wrong.  Far from being a cheap knockoff,  SASRT proved to be an alternative of equal quality, sometimes even improving Mario Kart's formula when it comes to presentation (the game is surprisingly good looking with a smooth frame rate) and variety (well designed transforming tracks and vehicles have vastly different gameplay depending whether you're driving a kart, a boat or a plane).Furthermore, regardless of how much I absolutely loved Mario Kart 8 on Wii U, I cannot help but think that SASRT is just the superior game from my point of view: it's prettier (an easy 1080p, 60fps even on modest PC hardware), simultaneously more technical and fun to play (the game rewards skill and the randomness of items isn't as frustrating), with a much better solo campaign and varied challenges (the World Tour mode which includes, Ring Races, Boost Challenges, Boost Races, Drift Challenges etc..), complemented by a stellar soundtrack for fans of old school SEGA games (remixes of Golden Axe's Wilderness, Shinobi's Itaden and Japonesque, and Panzer Dragoon's Flight brought back childhood memories), and wrapped up by an absolutely whacky roster of misfits (Football Manager, Willemus and Danica Patrick.. serioiusly ? WTF ?! ).  What's not to like ?In closing I can only highly recommend SASRT to everyone, Steam Summer Sale price or not, most particularly to old school SEGA games nostalgic and Mario Kart fans.  It's the most fun I've had in a while and gets my absolute praise.  Bravo !

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
A great kart racing gameIt plays great. You feel a sense of speed and performing drifts and tricks is fun. I have a feeling that some of the people that worked on this game also worked on F-Zero GX. Compared to Mario Kart Wii, the cars control better. (I haven't played Mario Kart 8.)But it has some flaws. The menu has an very annoying announcer, the power-ups aren't that good and the music is not memorable. And although I did say it plays great, the physics can be weird sometimes and the track design questionable. Sometimes a small mistake can mean coming to a full stop and finishing the race close to last.This game can be hard. But in my opinion, that's what makes it great. And to add variety, you also race by airplane and by boat, with the tracks often transforming themselves, It will keep you on your toes.People will instinctively compare this game to Mario Kart. But it's closer to F-Zero and Diddy Kong Racing in terms of gameplay. And that's OK with me.If you're looking for a kart racing game to add to your Steam collection, this is the one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												So, when Sonic & All-Stars Racing first came out, everyone pretty much just passed it off as a Mario Kart clone that would never quite make it. But, with this installment, it blows that idea out of the water. This is better than Mario Kart. While it has less in the way of more well-known characters and wacky items, it has its own charm with nostalgic favourites like Beat and Ulala from Sega's classics; alongside representatives from their newer IPs; all the while revelling in cheesy dialogue from them all and a range of dynamic, stunning tracks to race around. It doesn't try to be something so much greater than Mario Kart or similar family racing games; but pulls it off anyway - it's just wild and fun, The fact that rubber-banding effects are really lessened in this game is particularly welcome, although it still has its own type - the All-Star moves; although they are fun in their own way.All in all, highly recommended for anyone who's getting a bit old for Mario Kart or just wants to try something new.

												Awesome. 9/10Nostalgic & classic, yet also very competitive, challenging and has incorporated diverse styles of gameplay within the races. This game is controller friendly and fun for pretty much anybody wanting to have a casual jam session. Great for multiplayer/online gameplay.The different race tracks are beautifully structured and the classic iconic characters fit the themes of their cars so well. The interace has a really classic arcade layout but the frames are well polished. I love the graphics... I don't know how some people could complain about them. This isn't meant to be a realistic driving simulator, it's an SEGA-themed arcade racing game.The composition is a masterpiece. I love the textures and rich lighting that give the game a warm, vibrant and fast paced racing environment.I never thought I would find so much joy in what originally appeared to be too 'childish' for a grown man to play but the game is just awesome. I hope that other manly men with beards still feel manly after playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												A surprisingly coherent racing experience. The AI is genuinely challenging (and not in the typical racing rubberbanding kind of way) and playing online against others is legitimately fun, even when you lose. If you're a fan of Sega franchises and characters, you'll find that you'll likely have one or two characters you'll enjoy racing as. There's even a handful of third party characters that were all crossover promotions. The differences between the characters are all pretty subtle, and the modifications offer a great way to adjust your favorite character(s) to be more in line with your playstyle. Some of the picks for characters are odd (Danica Patrick?) and others are clever.The tracks themselves are interesting, all based on Sega franchises. Unsurprisingly, there's a ton of Sonic-related levels, but lots of other franchises get representation in stage form, as well.My only gripes with the game comes with the learning curve. You'll find that after two or three races, driving and boating sections will become second nature, and it'll take a few more races to learn tricks. The problem comes when you first encounter a track with flying elements. Probably the worst sections of the game, I dread when tracks are chosen that focus on flying because it's clearly the section of the game that was worked on the least, and should have been left out of the game. My guess was that they wanted to go for a Diddy Kong Racing dynamic with this one and couldn't leave flying out. It would have been a far, FAR better game without it.The other modes that aren't racing are half-baked at best and completely unenjoyable at worst. The game's engine is clearly not made for anything other than actual racing, and it shows when you play battle modes or Capture the Chao. You'll want to steer clear of those game modes completely and focus on just racing.Otherwise, the game is a coherent racing experience and is legitimately enjoyable. It's fast paced, and the weapons are fairly easy to utilize (though some require a bit of skill to use effectively). The sense of speed on some tracks is fairly exciting, and it's possible to boost almost constantly on a number of tracks, rewarding skilled players but offering a learning challenge to new players. Highly recommended to support this game in hopes of a sequel that removes the flying aspects.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is possibly the best Kart racer I have ever played.  Having grown up as a SEGA fanboy, this is the SEGA answer to Mario Kart that I always wanted and the PC version definitely gives Mario Kart 8 a run for its money! It's also a great livingroom PC/HTPC game, as it supports up to 4 players on a single screen (local splitscreen.)The tracks are varied and well designed, with plenty of shortcuts and bonuses which reward skilled players.  Being a huge SEGA fan from back in the day, I really appreciated the call-backs and themes the levels offered (Golden Axe, Shinobi, Skies of Arcadia, and more!)As far as difficulty is concerned, this game is no cakewalk.  There is a learning curve involved in teaching yourself how to drift, how to boost, and how to stack boosts in order to be competitive, but the game greatly rewards you for building your skill.  Beware: The A.I is absolutely cutthroat and they won't show you any mercy while you're still getting used to things.  While at first they seem to be absolutely unfair, they can be overcome with practice and skill as well as knowledge of the track.  They do not rubber-band to the player like Mario Kart's opponents do in older entries.  There are items which you can use to attack/sabotage other drivers just like in Mario Kart, however they play less of an important role in SASRT, as you will not find yourself getting item-spammed at inopportune times if you're good enough to get ahead of the pack.The tracks themselves can change lap-to-lap and new situations may require a new type of vehicle.  That's where the "transformed" part of the game's name comes in.  Each vehicle is capable of transforming from a car to a boat to a plane and back again, depending on the level's terrain.  The transformations are automatic (so you don't have to worry about having the wrong vehicle type at the wrong time) and they add a great variety to the overall gameplay.  There is a learning curve involved in learning the different handling of each vehicle type (especially the planes), but they are not difficult to get a hang of.Each character has unique stats and abilities and they can be leveled up through racing and completing events/challenges.  When leveling up, you can unlock 'mods' which drastically alter your character's stats and can be helpful on certain courses (for example, the handling mod will boost cart handling and can help on an icy stage with lots of turns.)Another huge advantage that this game has over Mario Kart is its Single Player campaign.  While Mario Kart only really offers a Grand Prix and Time Trial mode for its single player experience, SASRT offers both of those plus a "World Tour" mode in which players must complete a wide variety of events (races, drift challenges, boost challenges, combat race challenges, etc) to earn stars which can be used to unlock additional characters as well as stat/kart upgrades.  If you want, you can even play local multiplayer in World Tour mode (up to 4 players) and everyone can take on the challenge simultaneously. I found that I got a good 30 hours of gameplay out of World Tour so far and I haven't even 100% finished it yet; there's lots of content to be had!I highly recommend this game to any fans of racers, Sonic, and SEGA franchises of old.  You won't find a better Mario Kart alternative on PC (short of emulation.)

Fun little game and a nice addition to any cart racing fan's collection 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This is a worthy successor of Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing. It improves on it and is currently the best competitor for Mario Kart. It may be a little inferior to the Nintendo kart racing, but it's still an awesome game for this genre. Plus, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed isn't a Nintendo exclusive. Like the title implies, this time around you race in 3 vehicle types: car, boat and plane. And you'll frequently change between these vehicles during the same race. The car plays almost the same as the original title, which focuses on gaining extra speed through drifting and boosting. The car is stable and easy to control. You can also drift and boost on boats and planes, but the boat sections are more focused on hitting ramps to perform stunts to earn boosts and the plane sections are more focused on hitting boost panels in a more straight line, while also evading the course obstacles to get extra boosts. The boat is harder to maneuver because of the water waves and because it's harder to turn. The plane is more straightforward, with the added verticality to control. But sometimes it can be a little stiff, especially during sharp turns. But overall, the vehicle switch mechanic is fluid and the physics are great for all of them. The carrer mode is essentially the same as the previous title. World tour to me felt like the original mission mode, but more organized with added unlockables. Gran prix is just that, a series of 4 races awarding points in each race based on the final position. But this time you can't restart in the middle of it, and that's how it should be to me. Time trials are the same, but this time with added leaderboards. And of course, there's single race. The game is also way harder than the original, and the expert difficulty is hard, with some events being very hard, like some of the time trial ghosts. But it's doable with some practice, and as you play and experiment you'll get better. There's also online mode, which isn't quite dead yet, but i didn't spent much time on it. The character and track selection is also better than the original. While some characters were removed, there's plenty of new ones. Some are from the same game as others, some from other SEGA titles, some 3rd party ones (e.g. Team Fortress), and even a real life rally racer that here drives a Hot-Wheels on land. This selection feels better and more diverse, even with the removed characters. The tracks are also cooler. There's only 16 tracks (not counting 4 returning ones), but they are more diverse, longer and change mid-race, so the 3 laps aren't always the same. Added with the vehicle switch and good design for the most part, these tracks are a blast to play on. They are also beautiful as well as the graphics, a real eye candy. The soundtrack is also cool. This time the tracks are arrangements instead of ripped songs, and they work pretty well (i love the Golden Axe arrangement on Adder's Lair, as well as this course). If you like kart racing games, this is an easy recommendation, even if you think that you may like it. It may take some time for beginners to get good, but it's definitely worth it.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												A lot of people think this game is just a copy of Mario Kart 7, due to the flying and boat transformations. However, alot of people don't know that Sega had the Idea first. I bought the original game on my DS. Not very good graphics or gameplay. Then I saw this game on sale, and I couldn't stop myself from buying it, as well as a little bit of DLC. This game is amazing. 10/10. The graphics have improved, though that may just be my opinion because of the DS' graphics. The gameplay is better than Mario Kart. In Mario Kart 7, during the flying sections, you don't feel much control. Sonic & All-Stars Racing: Transformed fixes that. At first I didn't realize I had much power over flying, so I ended up in last place. I even had the game turn on Y-axis. Also the game's cast of characters are great. Wreck It Ralph, Yogscast, Pyro, Heavy, and Spy all make appearances. Well, Pyro, Heavy, and Spy make up one team called Team Fortess, so, does that still count? I'm saying yes. Anyways, if this game wasn't on sale I probably wouldn't even try it. But, I ended up loving it. Man, I love this game.

												What at first seems like a poor man's Mario Kart turns out to be one of the largest, most polished, and, most importantly, balanced, kart racers ever made. There's no rubber band AI or Blue Shells here, the majority of races are won with one thing and one thing alone: skill. Sure, items can help or hinder your position, but they'll never be a complete game changer. Topped off with gorgeous courses, a soundtrack composed of both original pieces and remixed ones, and plenty of content, All-Stars Racing Transformed is incredibly fun and sure to keep you racing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a lot of fun and really improves on its predecessor. The gameplay is smooth and responsive and the races feel action packed. There is a large variety of weapons to thwart your competition and a good variety of brilliantly designed courses. The courses never get boring because a number of them alternate between being ground based, water based and aviation based depending on the lap or course you are on. Different characters start off with and transform into different vehicles suited to the type of race. Each individual character also earns different 'mods' for their vehicles when they level up which alter their stats.  The announcer from the previous game is no longer in it and instead it is just spectated when you are "owning the race" or have performed a stunt or attack. The soundtrack is as good and as fitting  as ever with some really well done remixes. You can play with up to four players but playing against the AI also offers up a worthy challenge depending on the chosen difficulty. Playing on a higher difficulty rewards you with more stars which are used to unlock more characters, courses and bonuses.The are only two things that grate on me about this game, one being the inclusion of characters that just don't seem to fit such as 'Danica Patrick' who appeared in the game because she was sponsored by Sega. In my opinion it would have been better to include some more well known characters such as Kazuma from the Yakuza series which was by Sega. On the upside there were a few DLC characters that were added for free. The final annoyance is that I have found the game sometimes crashes to desktop for no apparent reason. This is no reason to not buy the game (because it is a justified purchase that offers a shed load of fun) but it can induce some serious rage when you're in the middle of a race or have just set up a multiplayer session.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
http://clickbliss.net/post/92637780532/why-i-love-sonic-all-stars-racing-transformed"Sumo Digital have obviously learned something from their time working on the Outrun series, because this has some of the best feeling drift mechanics since the 2006 entry. Essentially a Mario Kart style powerslide mechanic, All Stars simplifies it to a single button press and demands that you master it to properly navigate the course. Basically if you’re not drifting at every opportunity you're doing it wrong. Seriously, the drifts in this game put Initial D to shame. Also, you can drift in a plane. All Stars manages to one up Mario Kart as well by actually being fair. While there are a mass of powerups, each one of them can be countered or avoided with skill, removing the slot machine 8th to 1st overtakes of the Mario Kart series. It also means brutal online competition. Seriously, if you think you can drive just wait until you see the online community. "

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Probably one of the best racing games I've played in a long time. Everything is smooth, and flows really well. It's super easy to get the hang of (although I use an Xbox controller). Some controls are iffy and a little annoying, like trying to throw something behind you, but it's not a huge issue. Story mode is just as fun as multiplayer, and it has an impressive roster with plenty of nostalgia from other characters as well as new ones (Wreck-It Ralph is my favourite). Some voice acting is just plain terrible though, like the TF2 character(s). But it's not much to complain about.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												This game was a relief for me. I don’t know why I bought it, I got it on a sale, just because it was cheap. And WOW, what a surprise! It’s fun! Simple as that. The levels are awesome and there are very well designed. My favorite one is the “After Burn Stage”, a Nascar like track with the three different vehicles. You also have some sort of customization, for hardcore gaming. Full Speed with low handling. You can play this game with the whole family with a Mario party feel, and also do some hardcore time attacking by yourself.It’s an excellent game that I would recommend buying at its full price with all the DLCs. It’s not an AAA game, but its simplistic fun and awesome gameplay captivated me. Pros:Fun – Simple as that.Excellent GraphicsOptimized for PC GamingNostalgic Stages – You will feel your childhood coming back by visiting those classic stages Dynamic and well-designed levels. Con:The game is not keyboard friendly – I recommend you using a controllerItems – If you like racing games, be aware that it has the same “issues” as every “kart” racing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												I usually don't like racing games but this... this is addicting.I mean it's so fun, I don't know half of these guys because I'm not a Sonic/Sega fan but they do seem a charismatic and diverse bunch!The items are straightforward and there aren't much of them, but they're different and easy to use after some practice.The driving requires a good amount of skill between drifting, acrobatics and other stuff that helps you boost your speed.All in all, it's easy to learn, but hard to master.I like the fact that your "car" or kart becomes a boat or even a flying jet (!) in certain areas and it's a totally different feeling, like, flying is not a dumbed down version of a car, you go up down whenever you like and the boat is hard to maneuver.I've been having TONS of fun with this battling against friends online or inviting guests like my girlfriend, plugging 2 controllers and playing, you can even combine controllers + keyboard and then go to an online match!Overall, as a guy that doesn't like racing games, I loved this one, probably the first and the last, recommended for parties at your house or just plain fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is a solid addition to the "Kart Racing" genre. I put kart in quotes because there are no karts in this game. What there are instead are some pretty solid cars, planes and boats that all control and handle how they should do. In this game I never find myself annoyed at the game for how it plays, if something goes wrong usually it's my fault.I also like the difficulty in this game as well, it's not a "cheap" difficulty where you are bombarded with special items left right and centre, no. Oponents actually drive pretty well and don't seem to follow a set path but rather make decisions to throw you off.Is this game just another Mario Kart clone? Far from it, it's not even in the same league. I would play this over Mario Kart any day.The music, by English composer Richard Jaques, is pretty damn good. With remixes of some classic Sega tunes and some pretty good original compositions you really cannot go wrong with it. And yes, this is the same man that did the Catchphrase theme song (didn't go where you thought it would did you?)If I did have one complaint however (and this one works in MKs favour) the courses can be very long, almost too long so if you haven't got much time to play a game, this isn't the game for you.  Section Out of 10   Graphics 8   Music 8   Gameplay 9   Total 8.5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed for PC is the perfect alternative to Mario Kart of a fun and whacky racing party game, if you don't own a Nintendo console.As a racing game it doesn't have the deepest mechanics, but drifting, braking and reward for skill are all there, so there's nothing to dislike. As a racing party game, it has tons of content! Customization, varied characters, stages and fun powerups... everything you want to have fun with your friends. Online play and a lot of singleplayer content make it a good singleplayer experience.It's graphics are not super great though, but they do the job. It's music is a good selection although it isn't the catchiest. The selection of characters and stages though are kind of... ackward. Ignoring the fact that Wreck-It Ralph, Danica Patrick and Team Fortress are even in this game, the selection of characters from SEGA titles in the end seem weird and don't work all that well together. In comparision to Smash Bros. where all characters fit really well together, this game as a wide and weird array of characters that don't really match. Still, the ammount of SEGA representation is here including Amigo, NiGHTS and tons of Sonic characters, as you'd expect.The system of the track changing and the cars trasforming to planes and boats really is the mechanic that makes this game really stand out. Each vehicle has different yet similar mechanics making it so it's easy and simple for the player to change control schemes, while still making it varied. That being said, perhaps it's a little too similar since the tracks are always the same and the vehicles transform in select sections make it so that it really blends in to the game too much, making this unique mechanic not stand out as much. What I mean is that the tracks don't really take too much advantage of the three forms and doesn't unlock its true potential. You don't have a option most of the time to choose if you take a shortcut for the car or a vertical shorcut with the plane. It's always the same and there isn't too much freedom to transform. Still, it's a pretty neat mechanic and is worth checking out on its own.Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is perfect if you want a racing party game but you don't own a Nintendo console and it's worth checking out even on its own. It's a fun game for sure, but it's not groundbreaking and is not a real replacement to other party games since it's a PC game.Worth checking out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2013
												Easily the best kart racer of this generation, and probably the best one ever released on PC. It's not a dramatic departure from the formula invented by Mario Kart, but Sonic Transformed tweaks and improves upon that formula in a lot of ways that make it even better than Nintendo's more recent offerings. Weapons are a lot more fair and can be dodged with quick and careful driving. The single-player mode offers up a huge amount of missions with a lot of variety. The graphics are gorgeous. The trick system for earning boosts encourages learning the tracks. The three different vehicle modes all handle very differently. There's a lot of depth here if you want to dive into the time trials.And if you're into Sega, this has a ridiculous amount of fanservice. From Segata Sanshiro to Burning Rangers to Panzer Dragoon, this is the ultimate tribute to Sega's history.About the only major flaw is the inability to turn off weapons in online or grand prix play. Some of the single-player missions are weaponless races, and it's a real shame that you can't play like that with friends or in a racing series. But it's telling that I consider that a flaw - that the core racing in a kart racer is so good that I want to enjoy it without the accoutrements normally layered on top of games in the genre.

												For the people who are probably asking themselves "Is this game better than Mario Kart?"I want you to imagine this...Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed walks into a Taco Bell with nothing but a $20 bill, and he ain't gonna leave until it's all gone. One steak quesadilla, four soft shell tacos, three 5-layer burritos, a bag of Doritos and a medium Mountain Dew Baja Blast later, our friend concludes his visit to the establishment and decides to pay another to his dear friend, Mario Kart. Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed knocks on the door, the sound nearly drowned out by the churning of his own stomach. Mario Kart answers the door. "Hey, Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed, what's up?", he asks inquisitively, wondering why his friend is visiting at such a peculiar hour unannounced. Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed replies "Oh, not much, I was just in the area and-OH MY GOD, what is THAT!?". Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed points in a general direction behind Mario Kart. Mario Kart turns to look at what could cause such a stir, but nothing is there. In this instant, Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed undoes his own belt, pulls down his pants and aims his♥♥♥♥♥towards his neighbor. Confused, Mario Kart's head turns back to it's default position to discover his friends exposed, crowning ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ staring directly into his eyes. Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed proceeds to blow a violent fiesta of watery♥♥♥♥♥♥chunks all over Mario Kart's stupid, fat ♥♥♥♥ing face, staining it forever brown.That's how much better this game is than Mario Kart.EDIT: I wrote this review before Mario Kart 8. MK8 is pretty much just as good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Has pretty much everything you want out of a kart racer:  balanced power-ups, great level design, large cast of characters, plenty of challenge, smooth online play, local multiplayer, and some fantastic visuals.  If you can look past the fact that you might not recognise some of the racers then you have no reason not to give this game a try.  Seriously, it's easily one of the best kart racing games ever made... it's up there with CTR, Diddy Kong Racing, and whichever Mario Kart you prefer.I know it can be easy to write this game off.  After all, how many Mario Kart clones did we see after the N64 version blew up?  But instead of merely copying another franchise and putting a Sega skin over everything, you'll quickly notice that the developers genuinely tried to take full advantage of every licence they got.  Putting as much detail as possible into each racer's kart and respective tracks.  The tracks are really well designed; they never get too long or feel too short, they contain plenty of variety thanks to the ability to jump between car/plane/boat, and often change dramatically as the race progresses.  The gameplay itself is a sweet mix of CTR and Diddy Kong Racing, but with their own unique take on the two.The game's one weak point (outside of maybe the initial learning curve) is some of the character selection.  While they do try to include plenty of female characters, a few of their choices are kinda lame side characters, but it's a minor complaint and the roster is otherwise very creative and varied.  Plus the PC version has 31 (!) total characters, which is great.If this is a style of game you enjoy or have ever enjoyed previously, I highly recommend picking this up.  If you can manage to play it with friends then you are in for some competitive gaming bliss.

Posted: December 10, 2013
												When I first saw Reddit singing songs of praise for Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed I was skeptical at best. After 21 hours of play time I can say the praise is well deserved. The carts are varied and customisable (leveling up the carts will eventually give you 7 stats mods variants to choose from). Boosting/power sliding is tight and responsive and tracks range from standard cart racing to a mixture land, sea and air which you switch between on the fly.With a roster of 29 characters, the option of 4 player local split screen and full controller support Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed really does hold its own in the cart racing genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												On a very bored Friday where I failed to attend my college course, I decided that the zany scrapes of Sonic, and his new friends including Team Fortress, Shogun and Football Manager was for me. I installed the game during its free weekend and had no issues installing, the download was fast and despite the relatively small file size, the game had amazing graphics, or at least, as amazing as you can get with hedgehogs and Team Fortress characters.My initial issues with the game included controls, the game is clearly designed for the use of controllers and more customised peripherals, like steering wheels with pedals. You cannot configure the controls or the graphic settings out of game which makes it quite annoying, especially if you're attempting to change your resolution or find out what runs best with your computer set up. When I finally got into the game and began to drive around (as expected, I was Sonic), the game was relatively straight forward, and perhaps I wasn't looking clearly enough but the presence of a tutorial is extremely lacking, and I found myself looking at the control lists to understand what I was doing.The multiple vehicle system was something very unexpected, but not entirely unwelcomed once I had adjusted. The boating system is a little awkward at first, but I eventually found myself enjoying the neat tricks you can perform once you're up in the water. Planes are extremely fun and as expected, driving is an absolute pleasure in this game. It's almost like driving along the higher hills of Scotland or Wales in the late summer.The game is particularly easier than most other driving games, due to the fact you have weapons, and aiming is extremely simple, you can disarm your opponents using balls of ice, fireworks (don't try that at home) or even pufferfish. It makes the game truly dynamic and forces you adapt at every turn, using every skill in your arensal to evade the traps your opponents have set out for you.The levelling system for your characters is extremely benefical, and allows you to customise your loadout depending on the map, this allows us to separate out the good drivers from the great ones, who will adjust their abilities according to their map. For people new to the game, the system helps ease them into customisation of their vehicles, but allows pro-players to efficiently edit their load-outs.If you've got nothing to do this weekend, I highly reccomend this game. It's a fun little timewaster, and even if you don't enjoy racing games, you will find yourself lost in it.10/10 from this Sonic fan!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is a solid addition to the "Kart Racing" genre. I put kart in quotes because there are no karts in this game. What there are instead are some pretty solid cars, planes and boats that all control and handle how they should do. In this game I never find myself annoyed at the game for how it plays, if something goes wrong usually it's my fault.I also like the difficulty in this game as well, it's not a "cheap" difficulty where you are bombarded with special items left right and centre, no. Oponents actually drive pretty well and don't seem to follow a set path but rather make decisions to throw you off.Is this game just another Mario Kart clone? Far from it, it's not even in the same league. I would play this over Mario Kart any day.The music, by English composer Richard Jaques, is pretty damn good. With remixes of some classic Sega tunes and some pretty good original compositions you really cannot go wrong with it. And yes, this is the same man that did the Catchphrase theme song (didn't go where you thought it would did you?)If I did have one complaint however (and this one works in MKs favour) the courses can be very long, almost too long so if you haven't got much time to play a game, this isn't the game for you.  Section Out of 10   Graphics 8   Music 8   Gameplay 9   Total 8.5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Easily one of the best racing games I've played, not just kart racing! While preventing the alienation of more casual players, the game manages to take the actual racing very seriously. There is an unusually high level of skill required to win in hard mode. It encourages that you learn the tracks and how to navigate them with effecient boosting, or you lose; I personally really enjoyed this!Racing against other experienced players, the items are very fun and I never felt cheated by them! All races can be won by pure skill alone; luck plays a rare factor. This is a welcome change from other popular kart racers, where victory can be determined by fire-and-forget homing attacks that cannot be prevented. Certain items in this game can even be avoided with a well timed boost, air dodge, or obstruction.Many of the stages are way better looking than I'd expect for a game of this type. There is a high level of artistry and aesthetic awareness all throughout. It looks truly fantastic at times!This is easily one of my favorite games graphically and it doesn't hurt it's a tremendous amount of fun to play! I recommend this to anyone who enjoys balanced and atypical racing.I like this game so much, I bought it for: myself, my ex, a friend, and repurchased it once it was released on PC. That should either be a testament to how great this game is, or how poorly I manage my money.The game has also been so cheap as of late, I would simply buy it to experience the visuals alone!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
A wonderful game that pays tribute to everything Sega, Sonic and All-Stars Racing Transformed is something that will crush the competition for years to come.The Good:Level Design and Diversity: S&ART's levels come in many different shapes and sizes, and all of them provide a rich, detailed and fun experience for the players. From challenging levels make Rainbow Road look easy to wonderfuly crafted thematic levels such as  Dream Valley, S&ART has a level for every skill level. Character Diversity: Every vehicle and level in S&ART has it's unique style and feel and style. From General Winter's Tank to Shogun's wooden... Chariot, The level of character diversity in S&ART easily surpasses the majority of arcade racing games on the market.The Notable:The Boats and Planes: The addition of boats and planes has opened up many unique opportunies for fun and often whacky levels. However, this is no Skydrift or Hydro Thunder. The boats often feel slow and clunky, and the feeling of being in water is only kept there by the predictable wave effects. The planes are meant to be the fastest and most agile of the vehicles, and yet they feel very bloated and dance through the sky instead of cutting through the air. Drifting is also a very gimicked function on these two modes, and serves as a tie-in feature to keep the feel of the game consistent. Modes that aren't Racing: From 'Capture the Chao' to 'Battle Arena', secondary modes serve as mostly a distraction (albeit an intresting and somewhat fun one) from the core of the game. The fun that one may have is generally very inconsistent as these modes generally rely on utilising one feature of the game over and over again. The Bad:Poorly designed PC Menus: Graphical customisation cannot be done in game, it must be instead configured through an external menu. The placement of the menu items in game are also have a 'console port' feel, with clunky selection menus and awkwardly placed buttons.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2013
												Easily the best kart racer of this generation, and probably the best one ever released on PC. It's not a dramatic departure from the formula invented by Mario Kart, but Sonic Transformed tweaks and improves upon that formula in a lot of ways that make it even better than Nintendo's more recent offerings. Weapons are a lot more fair and can be dodged with quick and careful driving. The single-player mode offers up a huge amount of missions with a lot of variety. The graphics are gorgeous. The trick system for earning boosts encourages learning the tracks. The three different vehicle modes all handle very differently. There's a lot of depth here if you want to dive into the time trials.And if you're into Sega, this has a ridiculous amount of fanservice. From Segata Sanshiro to Burning Rangers to Panzer Dragoon, this is the ultimate tribute to Sega's history.About the only major flaw is the inability to turn off weapons in online or grand prix play. Some of the single-player missions are weaponless races, and it's a real shame that you can't play like that with friends or in a racing series. But it's telling that I consider that a flaw - that the core racing in a kart racer is so good that I want to enjoy it without the accoutrements normally layered on top of games in the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a lot of fun and really improves on its predecessor. The gameplay is smooth and responsive and the races feel action packed. There is a large variety of weapons to thwart your competition and a good variety of brilliantly designed courses. The courses never get boring because a number of them alternate between being ground based, water based and aviation based depending on the lap or course you are on. Different characters start off with and transform into different vehicles suited to the type of race. Each individual character also earns different 'mods' for their vehicles when they level up which alter their stats.  The announcer from the previous game is no longer in it and instead it is just spectated when you are "owning the race" or have performed a stunt or attack. The soundtrack is as good and as fitting  as ever with some really well done remixes. You can play with up to four players but playing against the AI also offers up a worthy challenge depending on the chosen difficulty. Playing on a higher difficulty rewards you with more stars which are used to unlock more characters, courses and bonuses.The are only two things that grate on me about this game, one being the inclusion of characters that just don't seem to fit such as 'Danica Patrick' who appeared in the game because she was sponsored by Sega. In my opinion it would have been better to include some more well known characters such as Kazuma from the Yakuza series which was by Sega. On the upside there were a few DLC characters that were added for free. The final annoyance is that I have found the game sometimes crashes to desktop for no apparent reason. This is no reason to not buy the game (because it is a justified purchase that offers a shed load of fun) but it can induce some serious rage when you're in the middle of a race or have just set up a multiplayer session.
