												A great racing/karting game. You get to play as many of the most famous SEGA characters including Ulala, Shogun, Nights and ofcourse Sonic & friends + some guest stars like Ralph from Wreck it Ralph movie or Team fortress dudes. But probably the most interesting and entertaining thing is the transformer-like nature of the cars which can transform to speedboats or jets depending on the situation on the track which usually changes with each lap so you end up running a pretty much different track in the last lap than you were running in the first one! In addition to racing you also get a lot of various challenges and unlockables and achievements so it's definitely worth buying. Don't be mislead by the fact it's a children friendly game, it gets very challenging on harder difficulties and in harder challenges.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												This is probably the best Mario Kart / Crash Team Racing -like game on PC, no doubt, but it has so many flaws that I can't recommend it to competetive gamers. I'll break them into sections.GraphicsThe screenshots on the store page look kind of good, but even with max settings, the character models are horrible, maps are ugly and low res and it doesn't really have all that much of eyecandy like in the screenshots. Plus, more often than not, the maps glitch and sometimes essential objects are missing, like the track you're supposed to drive on. YMMV (your mileage may vary) though.Game ModesThis is actually the best part of the game, the offline content. It took me and my gf over 20 hours to play through the main mode 100%, before we moved to Grand Prix. Main reason why it took so long was probably that it wasn't quick to become good at this game and we never moved on to the next track unless we beat the last on the highest difficulty. This is also how I recommend playing the game, otherwise it's probably too easy. It doesn't matter which of the human players wins the race and that makes this game highly cooperative.Online MatchmakingI've only read that the skill rating is brutal and connection issues are everywhere, which makes your rating drop if you drop out of a match. I tried to play this game online, but never found a match, so in my case the online game is dead. Again, YMMV. I wouldn't buy this game to play online, unless you get a good deal for a 4 pack or something with your friends.DrivingThe most important aspect of any racing game is how the controls work or how the cars (and planes and boats) handle. In car mode, it's quite okay and highly rewarding to combo boosts to get faster. But this is also where the game falls flat. The stats that the cars have are way inbalanced. Pick one of the most overpowered characters (like Gum or Alex Kidd) and you have an easy game, even in the highest difficulty. But if you have a favorite character and it has multiple handicaps stat-wise, good luck. Some of the maps and A.I. require near god-like performance to beat, plus the A.I. cheats. I'll write more about A.I. later. Now, there are the plane and boat -modes too. Plane is okay, fastest of the three, but not really fun or challenging. You can air drift and try to cut corners, but otherwise this is the most boring of the modes. You can easily land shots even with the aim dependant weapons, the drones and wasps really f♥♥k the A.I. up in plane mode and it's just... boring. Plus some of the maps have invisible walls, so you need to take the long route even if you could easily just fly straight to your destination, because there are no obstacles. Not really annoying as it's so rare, but a "feature" none the less.Boats... God I hate boats. Turning with a boat feels like you're playing with a 200ms lag. Plus you often overdo it, because turning just a bit feels like it's doing nothing. Then you overcompensate it to the other direction and you're head first at a wall, losing precious seconds and getting last. You can learn how to play with boats, but that takes a bit of the character variety out of the game, because if you learn how to do it with one character, the next might perform differently. Plus some of the maps just have the most ridiculous unfun water parts that you'll just be glad when you've beaten the map.CharactersThere are a lot of characters in this game, didn't bother to count them, but unlocking them makes the offline modes rewarding. Now one of the biggest cons in this game is how the basic stats of some characters are just irreparably underpowered. High handling is mostly useless beyond level 3 and some of the characters have like lvl 4+ handling and that is compensated with a slower car. It's ok in Drift challenges and maybe Ring Races, but in regular Races it's a recipe for last place.If the first 2 stats (speed and acceleration) are low on the character, you might try to level them up and fix it with mods, but often it doesn't do enough. I understand that most of the variety in character comes from their stats, but it just makes some of the maps unforgivably hard in higher difficulties. Though, when you get better at the game, you can beat most maps with any character, like I did in my replay. I started over and only picked random characters for each race and didn't have problems. But sometimes you get Amigo for a Sprint race (beat the A.I.s best lap time) and you're in for a bad time. Overall, not a big con, any other game has better and worse characters, so it's just basic game design.Some of the characters are just annoying and badly mixed voicelines break the immersion. Don't get the Yogscast DLC or you'll hate him everytime you play against him. Shadow and Joe Musashi (?) speak with their radio voice and that doesn't really fit in the sound design. That's a small annoyance, but one nevertheless. And don't bother playing bad with A.G.E.S because he'll comment every crash and burn like it's your fault, which might be true but god, does he need to turn the knife in the wound? :DGlitchesThese need their own section. Bugs and glitches are so abundant in this game, that it's the main reason the game has turned into a swear-fest for me. It is just too frustrating having to restart a race over and over again, because either your character is prone to physics glitches (randomly getting flown up in the air, the car doesn't turn because it is considered being in the air etc.) or the map is glitchy. And none of these will ever be fixed for this version of the game. The last update was that Ryo character in 2014. So if you're getting this game, consider it glitchy from the get go. The maps are glitchy and the characters are glitchy. If you combine the two, you're in for a restart-fest. Otherwise you need to play the map all the way to the end and start again anyway. That is, if you want to unlock it all, like I do.A.I.In lower difficulties the A.I. is super easy and slow, but in the harder difficulties expect to get hit from all sides with all kinds of weapons that makes you lose precious seconds. It's in the game design, yeah, but the A.I. isn't really fair in the first place. It would be ok, if the A.I. was affected by the same bugs as you, but no. They get overpowered boosts, they fly through tricky and tight corners with ease and sometimes they get so far ahead it's impossible to catch up. Start button, restart, choose difficulty, smash A will become a mantra when playing this game. You'll restart so often for the tiniest reasons just because the A.I. does stuff you can't counterplay. Sometimes they target you as a group and that means you will want to restart, again and again.Map DesignMostly it's ok and fun, but the haunted house map is an example of annoying map design. 90 degree turns after a high jump? Doesn't really play well with the high speed feel of the game, having to slow down. Some maps have routes that are just super annoying and once you learn them you'll never go there again. Like the snowy map, you'll never want to go via the high route because it's one of the glitchiest parts of the map. Anyways, you'll have your favorites and pet peeves.ConclusionI don't know why I bothered to write such a long review for a 5€ game that is actually most of the time fun. The fun just gets undone if you don't get bored of the game before unlocking everything. The game becomes frustrating with all the issues and unfairness of the A.I. that will never be fixed. Without them, this would be near perfect kart racer for PC but we're left with an abandoned port that works with casual gamers. If Steam had other options than recommending a game, I'd happily give it something in between. With stars it would probably be something like 3/5.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												Suppose i'll be the first to review in the open, i'm going to be a sport and say 4/5.It's a well presented game that is really well optimised.Real go getter for avid sonic fans, the soundtracks are very true so sonic of our spined friend's original days.Controls are a breeze, lovely colourful backgrounds and variation in gameplay that will keep you on you're toes, there's unlockables and achievements to be had based on player skill and lots of challenges for the player to attempt, a large selection of alternative game modes and above all else, it's fun.If you buy this one, i would have to say that if you don't quite get onboard with being hit with a rocket when you're in the lead, might be best going for another one, but as far as competive racing games go, i like it.Graphics : 4/5Great designs on maps although, visually nice to see, however, the wave textures are a little sloppy and at times they can interfere with control, though this is something that isn't that much of a problem.Sound : 4/5Decent, stereo sound tracks that display a little creativity on some original work of the previous sonic games, voice cast is those of familiar faces.Gameplay : 3/5Only discernable letdown is that there isn't an option for online grad prix modes, though there is plenty of room for exploration and a mountain of power-ups to gain the upper hand in races, help text is also shown between loading screens that will inform newcomers to a set weapon's function, over all a decently balanced expierience.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2013
												Finally... after all this time, a really, really, really decent Sonic game. Ok, maybe not in the traditional sense, but man, is this game fun ! There's a lot of variety in tracks, there are multiple routes to take, racers to level up, characters to unlock, stickers to collect and so much more. And then there's the transforming of your vehicle. You'll transform (next to your kart) into a plane and boat on the fly. It's a great idea and gives the game much more dynamic. It's the kart racer PC games always wanted (true, Blur was great too), no doubt.The graphics are colorful and sharp, the sounds are ok-ish, the music is very good and wow, the game actually supports my Xbox controller out of the box. I remember previous Sonic games having trouble with this.It also runs at 60FPS and never dips below. It's a great PC port for a great price.Only downside - and please note that it's only a small one - is this silly/annoying announcer, which Sega uses for pretty much all their own games. He sounds a bit corny in this day and age. And to be honest, I expected something better on that front.This game is just excellent and deservers your money if you're into arcade racers ! The campaign mode will also last you quite a while so you don't need any friends to have fun ;)Get it ![Rating: 87/100]

												I was always a fan of Mario Kart, every other "Kart Racer" that came out seemed to be just a knockoff which was never much good. The first SASASR was a "Kart" game. At first I avoided it as I was playing Mario Kart Wii at the time. When I got round to playing sasasr I was shocked as it blew MKW out of the water. It was faster had missions and was genrally more fun. When this came out I bought it straight away on the PS3. This is an "Arcade racer" as opposed to a "kart racer" so it handles totally different to its predecessor. This game is fantastic its so much faster than Sassar and makes that feel slow. This has loads of  challenges and fantastic levels. The levels come alive and terraform during the race. The Skies of Arcadia map starts off with ground air and boat, but by the end of the second lap the Sky Pirates invade have a massive fight and blow most of the circuit away turning it into a air only circuit. I currently have about 98% complete on the PS3 the final time trails are so hard so I dont think I will ever get the 100%! I was also within the top 100 on the championship standing at one point. I Would recommend this game to anyone who like racing games that are more on the fun side!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I unfortunately can't get into Mario Kart anymore since the "Mario Party" design philosophy of handicaps and handouts has invaded the item system so thoroughly. But I am happy to find that Sonic All Stars Racing is a modern kart racer that maintains a lot of the things I loved about the Mario Kart games without all the Mario Party everybody-is-a-winner welfare gimmicks.Here is a list of comparisons that I think highlight which game is better than the other in which areas. You may or may not agree.Short version: Mario Kart destroys Sonic in charm, but Sonic is a better racer. Choose Mario for a more artistic, more cohesive, and more atmospheric racing experience. Choose Sonic if you want to actually enjoy driving.QUALITY OF TRACK AESTHETIC:Mario Kart 8 is the clear winner. Much more creative, vibrant, and fun-looking tracks.CUSTOMIZATION OPTIONS:Both games have some customization, but MK8 is better here, allowing you to choose your vehicle model and exchange individual parts. Sonic only allows you to choose "mods" which are just preset stat configurations but don't change your vehicle appearance in any way.CHARACTER/RACER QUALITY:Suffice to say, Nintendo has a much longer list of memorable characters with tremendous pedigree. Plus the characters in Mario Kart feel COHESIVE, which is to say they all FEEL LIKE they are part of the same universe and should be in the same game together. In comparison, the character options in Sonic All-Stars Racing are pretty underwhelming. The characters don't have the same pedigree, they have completely inconsistent art styles, and there is virtually no cohesion whatsoever--i.e. most of the characters don't feel like they should be in the same game together at all. It's just a random hodge-podge of characters from all over the place, many of which you may not have heard of and probably don't care about. It's weird that Sonic characters are racing next to Team Fortress 2 characters. Even weirder is when REAL race car drivers (e.g. Danica Patrick) start showing up. Just... a weird mix. But I love racing the classic Sonic characters.OPPONENTS USING ATTACK ITEMS THAT HOME IN ON YOU AND ARE IMPOSSIBLE TO SHAKE/AVOID:Mario Kart 8: There are multiple items like this and you get hit by them constantly (this is where a lot of the frustrating Mario Party-esque handicaps and handouts come from).Sonic: There are multiple items that have some degree of homing or aim-correction, but all homing attacks allow the *possibility* of avoiding them completely, e.g. by drifting around a sharp turn or around a solid object to make the incoming threat crash, or by firing your own attack items backward to neutralize the threat directly. Mario Kart used to be pretty good about letting skilled drivers pull off these types of exciting escapes, but more recent Mario Karts are more interested in handicapping skilled racers and giving welfare to less skilled racers. Sonic has a certain amount of balancing (as all racers do), but it still allows skilled racers to finish a race miles ahead of the competition if they are good enough.CAN SPEED BOOST BY PERFORMING STUNTS/TRICKS:Both games technically have this, but it is a lot more satisfying in Sonic. MK8 pretty much just has you press the jump/hop button to perform a standard trick, but in Sonic you can flick the right joystick to front flip, back flip, or barrel roll. And of course the barrel roll can also be used to avoid obstacles/attacks sometimes (especially during flying sections), which is always exciting.CAN SPEED BOOST BY DRIFTING:Both games allow you to do it, but the drifting feels better in Sonic. It just feels better to control. Also, even though the Sonic tracks aren't as charming as the MK tracks, they provide you with TONS more stunt and drift opportunities.SECRET SHORTCUTS & SIDEPATHSBoth games have these in equally satisfying amounts. That's in terms of quantity anyway. Bear in mind that Mario Kart tracks are more visually striking/creative, and the same goes here, but the Sonic tracks are not bad at all.VEHICLE TRANSFORMATIONS:Both games have the racers travel over all kinds of terrain: land, water, and air. But in Mario Kart it's mostly just terrain. In Sonic, your vehicle actually literally transforms between car, boat, and plane. Each of these forms of your vehicle controls completely differently and has to contend with completely different physics. The boat racing in particular can be very challenging--especially when racing across choppy water full of whirlpools and huge waves, etc. Sonic also has much more exciting flying sections, IMO. Lots of fly-through opportunities for daring flyers. And dat barrel roll.TRANSFORMING TRACKS:Sonic wins here. The tracks themselves transform as you race on them. There are a few tracks that are static through the whole race, but many tracks will change in some way. Either part of the track will get destroyed and then you'll drive off the end and transform into a plane, or a huge spaceship will land on the track, forcing all racers to drive inside/through it, and other such transformations. Some transformations are cooler than others, but the good ones are very fun.EMPHASIS ON COMBOS:Here is where Sonic really shines. Both Sonic and Mario Kart force you to use boosting if you want to stand any sort of chance against more advanced racers. However, I think Sonic does a better job of stringing together long chains of boost and stunt opportunities, letting you set up a huge combo chains. Since there are more types of stunts, mid-race vehicle transformations, and mid-race changes in the track itself, these combo chains can be very exciting. Sonic also makes it possible for you to FAIL your stunts if you execute them at the wrong time, so there is always an element of tension when you've got a good combo going. If you are a really good racer in Sonic, you can sometimes boost almost non-stop through an entire race.MINI-GAMES ETC:Mario Kart used to have battle mode, which was a huge selling point. For some reason they decided to get rid of it. Mario Kart 8 doesn't really have much in the way of other activities as a result, which is too bad.Sonic All-Stars Racing also does not have a battle mode, but if you select "world tour", there are some other racing activities you can do, such as drifting challenges and boosting challenges. I am personally a big fan of the TRAFFIC challenges, which fills one of the game's tracks with hundreds of other cars and tasks you with making good time while avoiding any crashes. (There are even police cars that try to ram directly into you!) Mario Kart would have posed a huge challenge if it still had battle mode, but with the absence of battle mode, Sonic's other driving activities win here.RUBBER BANDING:All racing games do it. MK8 and Sonic both do it. But I have to admit, even though Sonic is not as cheap as MK8 with items, it can be VERY cheap with the rubber banding on the A class races.OVERALL:Mario Kart has established itself as a kart racer that puts all racers on relatively equal ground, regardless of skill level. This is great for a group of friends with relatively equal skill level, but can be frustrating or even infuriating for skilled players who are held back by all of the constant handicaps.Sonic is not as good as Mario Kart in a number of ways, but it manages to be a fun kart racer that is very similar to Mario Kart, but it has more to offer players who want to win on account of driving skill and who are growing weary of Mario Kart's penchant for handicaps and handouts.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The game is beautiful, first of all. It is so colorful, and I enjoy playing it. However, there are things you must know before purchasing.1) You need a gamepad: Don't even think about playing this game with a keyboard and mouse. It is easy to configure the gamepad once you get to the configuration page OUTSIDE of the game.2) Glitchy: Some areas will count as off the road, even when you're on the road. Controlling the automobiles are a pain. 3) Read a guide: This game doesn't tell you about gaining boost during the start of the game, how to change directions while drifting, and anything else I forget. You have to read a guide if you want to get through the game. But the guides won't be long.4) Finish Grand Prix mode first: Dr. Robotnik is probably one of the easiest cars to maneuver, since it's so small and very fast. Unlock him to have him at your disposal during the mission mode.

												For shear driving pleasure out on the track, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is where it's at. I'm yet to find a game that does my G27 justice in the way that Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed has - On the limit of grip the feedback is superb and the physics/handling seem bang on to me. Whilst this is still an early build of the game and the content/features are a little light, what is there is fantastic. I have high hopes for future development of this game. In particular, a few Japanese cars wouldn't go a-miss. To summarise: if you're a motorsport fan, BUY IT! 9/10 for what's currently present.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												It's ♥♥♥♥in Mario kart for PC. Because Nintendo hates porting titles this is likely the closest thing we'll ever get. I don't have much to say as this essentially is the same thing except with flying and.. sailing? While Sailing is pretty much the same thing as driving and flying is a bit diffiuclt to get used to but has some fun parts. Anyways, if you ever liked Mario Kart this is essentially the same thing, perhaps a bit better. The game has a SEVERE lack of weapons though. Assuming you don't unlock weapons somehow it's a tad bit of a letdown. Got it for 7.50, the amount of levels is great for that price, just again, wish there were more weapons and more interesting ones. If Nintendo is going to remain console exclusive then I gotta give the props the SEGA here. They made a great game and haven't forgotten us. It even comes with splitscreen, a feature many PC games lack. Personally I doubt I'll see myself playing this online much, it's never interested me, so I'd price the game at around 15-20 dollars. But for people who want an online experience you can probably get a lot more out of this. 8.3/10

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												This is the best arcade style racing game that I have ever played. Even surpassing Mario Kart, which is also a supreme game title and very popular. Sega really pulled it off on this game, as they did with Sonic Generations. They just need to keep up the pace. I give this game a 9 out of 10. In the online ranked mode sometimes (not common but not rare either) you'll find a boost exploiter, or straight up cheater playing in the lobby. You can just avoid matchmaking if they pop up in your lobby though. Sega should ban them permanently from playing. That's my only complaint, is running into cheaters every now and then.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												The AI is a cheating bugger that rubberbands with the force of a nuclear weapon,  and will mess with you at every possible opportunity. No matter how fast you go, they will catch up and at the last possible second, they will steal your glory from you and laugh as you see that miserable 2nd place when a moment before you were 1st. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Okay here goes, most vet gamers have played this game already, it was called Mariocart, or Crash Bandicoot Nitrocart, or ____[Insert other kart game here like say Skunnykart on PC ☺] The game is fun, really fun, the tracks could make the fastest Falcon cringe from the vertical drops, and speed in places, but those are good things. They finally fixed online somewhere durring My break from this game, I just spent like 3 hours playing in two games online, for about 2 hours We had 8-10 players in the game, I noticed no real lag that effected Me, nor My vehicle, online you have to levelup your profile, and unlock characters seperate from career mode (a feature common now in games that I like), so lots'a replayability, but this game shines where Kart games are supposed to shine, multiplayer, so grab a friend, jump online, and "go fast"... Don't be discouraged when you never win a race at 1st, they're leveled up, and have mods for their vehicle, yours  will get faster too. This game fills a genre left open on PC of recent the "FUN multiplayer Kart game" it's worth just about any price, runs great on any old laptop (like Mine), and supports the worlds favorite PC controller the X-360 for windows pad, so pick it up, if you don't like it, then you don't like Kart games. ☻ Not as good as Crash tag team racing (THE best Kart game ever made, to bad it wasn't online), BUT this game is awesome!

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Wow. This game is really something special. I grew up on various kart racers, and this is so fresh yet so familiar. It is a joy to play on the bigscreen with a controller. On one hand, it is a cover of MarioKart, but yet on the other hand, it is very fresh and brings much more to the table. The problem with MarioKart is that it has not really aged all that well since the early 90's (IMO). Yes, it is still fun, but it needed to be overhauled - which is exactly what was done here.Pros:1. Wide range of difficulty from super easy to rage-quit-difficult.2. So many modes and tracks that the playtime hours stack up quickly.3. Awesome array of playable race characters ranging from Team Fortress to the Sonic Family and more.4. Tracks are video-game themed which is kick♥♥♥♥♥5. Graphics and sound are pretty great too.6. Meta-game character leveling up (something MarioKart should take notes on).7. There are still 3 laps, but usually in most tracks, each lap is different - your vehicle converts transformer-style into a boat, plane, and kart.Cons:1. The powerup concepts are borrowed heavily from MarioKart, yet are *slightly* underpowered. This meant that in MarioKart, it was anyones race pretty much up until the finish, which does not seem the case here. This basically translates to Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed requiring a bit more skill (if you will) to win any given race. This could be good or bad depending on how you look at it). I think I prefer the more random elements of MarioKart especially when playing with a group of friends with mixed skills/experience with Kart games.Overall, this game is totally worth full price in my opinion, and you certainly will not hear me say that often for a twenty dollar title.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Let's rock and roll!Well, where else can you find a good cartoonish racing game that's as fun as this? Game's been optimized for real, even my low end machine can play smoothly without lag - except internet problem during multiplayer - on medium-high settings. Graphic settings in-game allow you to fine tune the game to suit your preferences and rig. There's a major netcode weakness though- if you RTO twice in a row, bye bye multiplayer session and you'll earn a loss. Pretty weird since many multiplayer games have tendency to tolerate lags/delays (even in Dota 2 you can reconnect easily if you DC). Use of good and stable connection and playing with host in the same region are recommended. Moreover, this game implements peer to peer, so can't expect much stability when playing as it depends also on the host player. A shining MP game when it works.Now the gameplay, with many track selections in place, you won't get bored. From air battle to water fight, you name it all. The learning curve is incredibly steep as the differences among tracks are too great, you won't even be able compete effectively without any knowledge at all. Basically, it's a matter of skills, understanding of environment, and luck when it comes to rolling the weapons. Keep on repeating the same tracks until you understand what's the best choice to race in it. And of course you'd need to train the character you choose to play with. Each character comes with different allstars weapons, and different traits in race. Handling Sonic who is an all around racer, as opposed to AiAi's excelling when turning/braking would be a massively different style.Being a racing game, playing with controller is highly recommended. Can't recommend DInput as the button mappings are all wrong, but XInput or using XInput wrapper should be more than enough. F310 and Rumblepad 2 (with x360ce wrapper) work amicably with this game - XBOX360 is not even questionable. If you play with keyboard, drifting and jumping at the same time will prove to be quite problematic for the fingers. I'm not even sure how to perform both without being awkward.Single player experience has tons of stuffs to be done and unlocked. There's a world map split into smaller zones. Each zones has its own stage that give challenges in three categories - racing against bots/AIs, Ring Race (pass thru rings while flying within time allocated) and Time Attack (pass thru checkpoints when evading obstacles). Each challenge completion earns you a star, depending on your performance. With more stars collected you can get character mods, unlock more tracks and areas to play. Not to mention than doing Single Player is essential to improve your skill for multiplayer.One of a few games on Steam that I preordered and didn't regret it one bit.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Can't say enough about how awesome this game is! Still poses a challenge for adults, and yet easy enough for kids to play.The graphics are sweet, really improved over the previous Sega All stars game, sounds are great as always, and the gameplay is superb. At first I thought this was insanely difficult, and struggled to get 3 satrs on the first section of the game, but as I got used to the driving in this game, I started to really enjoy it. Just finished the "World Tour" section of the game, but still have a few things to unlock, and more stars to collect to do so. This, after playing most of it with my nephews - it's awesome how you can play the whole game local multiplayer, not just the multiplayer parts. Only spent about 13 hours in this game so far, but I expect it will be more like 30 hours before I can be happy I've exhausted it, and it'll most likely be something I'll pick up and play with others in months and years to come. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is racing at its finest-- its absolute finest. One could even say it surpasses Mario Kart! The game looks stunning and preforms almost completely without flaw. The characters are well balanced even if stats say otherwise. As an example, B.D. Joe has a high speed advantage, yet Amigo has a major speed disadvantage, but his acceleration and boost can bring him to first place if you know what to do. The tracks are filled with sega references and fill an old-school sega nerd's heart with joy. They're all fair and fun to race through on the ground, in the water, or even in the air. Whether you play alone or with friends-- it's all fun regardless. There are tons of missions to play through on easy, medium, or hard difficulties. Once you beat the game, you unlock an expert difficulty to really challenge yourself again! The game doesn't dry up fast at all; it's constantly keeping you racing. It doesn't matter if you're pro Nintendo or pro Sega, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is undeniably the best racing game to date.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												SASRT  (=Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed) might be a Mario Kart clone, but that doesn't stop it from blowing the original out of the water.Where Mario Kart games can really feel like they're mostly based on luck, SASRT is mostly  based on skill, even though you can still get a good item that would help you get the upperhand, but even then, you'll still have to use it wisely and have the skill to do so, or it will be completely useless.Where Mario Kart games' races can feel pretty uninspired, SASRT's races are a pretty great demonstration of intelligent level-design. Every single inch of the races are calculated to reward you if you're doing good and punish you if you screw up.Where Mario Kart games pace can feel  boring, SART's pace will barely allow you some time to blink.Where Mario kart games single-player will gladly leave you the  first place in any race on any difficulty setting and make sure the closest opponent stays a mile away from you, SASRT's AI will rather hunt you down and take you out like there's a billion dollars bounty on your headAnd don't get me wrong, I love Mario kart, especially Double Dash on gamecube. But Sega's SASRT is just so good it makes Mario Kart games looks like they're the SASRT clones.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Oh, where to begin with this game? Oh, I know; it's brilliant! While the model quality for most characters is rather poor (I'm looking at you, Sonic and Ralph) and the stock clips can be irrelevant a lot of the time, the true appeal in this game lies where it matters; the game play, especially in online mode. For hours on end you will find yourself racing head to head with up to ten friends, which can become highly competitive and addicting on many an occassion. Unlike the recent Mario Kart installments, your online race won't be ruined by an item similar to a spiny blue winged ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Instead, the items are fairly balanced (though I'd like to see a way to build up the All Star in future games) and the only item you can find yourself really getting frustrated at is the triple ice shot as it freezes you on contact. If you can live with mediaocre stock clips and alright character models (the environments themselves are overwhelming), I'd highly recommend this game on its online value alone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a joyous, colorful and pretty unique kart racing game that features a large number of characters and tracks mostly from various Sega games. Naturally, Sonic is the star here, but there are other characters here as well some of which you wouldn’t expect in this kind of game. The Steam version features additional characters from Team Fortress 2, Football Manager, Company of Heroes 2, Shogun: Total War and Total War: Rome II.The most unique concept that the game offers is right there in the title. Every car automatically transforms into a boat or a plane at different parts of the track. Not only that, but most tracks change from lap to lap as well. This makes the racing very dynamic, unpredictable and varied. The controls feels good, but they get more and more demanding as you change difficulty levels as the game automatically disables certain assists. Both casual and hardcore players can get the most out Transformed as you can change the difficulty at any time and enjoy the game at your own pace.Transformed doesn’t have a classic campaign, but it rather offers a World Tour consisting of a slightly non-linear series of a wide variety of events including classic races, battle races, versus, boost/drift/checkpoint challenges, and so on. This mode will unlock characters, tracks and mods. Mods let you slightly customize your vehicle in a very limited way. Each mod has a series of predetermined parameters which change up the ratios between speed, acceleration, boost, handling, etc. Apart from World Tour, there’s also Grand Prix which lets players compete in five tournament cups and time trial, single race and multiplayer.The graphics are great, the game is colorful and bright, each track is completely different both in its look and design. Unfortunately, the soundtrack is pretty much what you would expect from a game like this (or any Sega game, to be honest) – horribly cheerful retro synth and guitar melodies. Thankfully, it blends in well and you won’t notice it much at all.Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed does what it sets out to do very well. It’s simple and joyous yet challenging and skillful. The gameplay is fast and fun, the track design is varied and imaginative and there are plenty of modes that will keep you entertained for a long time.7 OUT OF 10 (GOOD)

												Online is a disconnect from servers simulator. so many times have i actually been able to do good in a race just to be told there was a network error that kicks me offline. worse yet theres a penalty for leaving an online race on your rating off 100 points, which is the most you can make in a single race which you get by completing the race in first but only when your rating is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Speaking of the rating system, it's ridicolous. the higher the rating you have, the less points you get for completing an online race. getting first place eventually reduces that 100 points  you earn to low amounts such as only 4 points. an example is 1st place will get you from 1100 to 1200, but if you're at 1600 you'll get around 40 points instead.  you even get less points taken away if someone with a high rating wins the race and more taken away if someone with a low rating wins the race. making a rating system (which is useless in video games anyhow...) even more useless.singleplayer requires you to be absolutely perfect at everything to unlock everything (including mods for characters that change vehicle stats) and the AI, like many reviews have said, cheats. items are even more bizzarre this time around, looking to have absolutely no influence from any of the games that the characters you play as come from.flying and driving physics are ok but water section are horrible due to actual water physics (such at a tiny wave turning you into a small rock skipping on water). my one problem with flying is that inability to fire backwards, which you can only do by holding backwards which causes your vehicle to nose-dive or fly directly upward, depending on your controls.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
The bad:-Weak characters. Although I'm far from unlocking the full set of characters in this game, the designs and vehicles go from okay (Tails, Wreck-it Ralph) to curious (Alex Kidd, Ryo) to friggin' awesome (Metal Sonic, Knuckles), to weak (Team Fortress) and finally to absolutely baffling. Football Manager, The *TWO* Total War characters and General Winter feel incredibly out of place and in the case of the last one, are kinda cringeworthy to drive while hearing WW2-era Soviet slogans and choral music when activating the special. And that's a shame, because I feel some of the designs are pretty neat but could have been way better if they had been designed as original themed characters instead of weak plug-ins for games that just don't belong in this game. I'm going to ignore Yogscast because it's the only thing that deserves, and only going to comment on the fact that it's kind of the sign that Sega really didn't care about making iconic, enduring, compelling characters opting instead for the founder of a podcast that not only has a history of publisher extortion, is an ugly and annoying turd in a box racer.Come on, Sega. You have way more franchises to take characters from than selling the spots in your game to the highest bidder. where's the OutRun car? Daytona USA?? Any of the Virtua games!? Golden Axe and House of the Dead could have been used for more than a track, and if we get into multi-platform characters there's a plethora from which to choose, from Sparkster to James Pond. Friggin' Battletoads. I could go all day. Tons of characters whose developers I'm sure would chip in to see fan interest in those properties renewed.Somewhat iffy controls on certain flips but especially when it comes to firing weapons. Plane sections require you to press up and down, which is also used to choose to fire in front or behind your vehicle. I would have preferred only shooting backwards when looking backwards, but that's more an annoyance than an actual issue.Nice tracks, but could be better, especially regarding the Sonic themed ones. They are pretty and nice, but with some notable exceptions like the Samba de Amigo or certain parts in the Nights levels, don't leave a very lasting impression.The good:Very tight handling and physics, that, although annoying sometimes if you get stuck, make sense and play fair. The game also has certain permissivity on roads that have no guards, letting you leave the track for a very brief moment and correct if you're fast enough. Flying sections feel especially alright.Very good  weapon system that allows to escape homing projectiles, neutralize attacks and choose how many and in what direction to fire your weapons. No blue shells to be found in this game.Challenging AI and demanding circuits that make clearing level A tracks an actual feat. Although difficulty seems pretty uneven letting you dominate certain circuits while sweating for every inch on others, you'll more than likely find yourself fighting teeth and nails over a position.Good variety of modes, including not just a grand prix option, but a progressive career as well, where you can unlock characters and advance through branching paths that offer different challenges.Splitscreen as well as online multiplayer.Versatility in characters, thanks to the unlockable mods for the cars that will emphasize some aspects of the vehicles, making possible to specialize a character in an area suited to your needs.Great music and sounds. For the most part. See "annoying turd in a box racer".My closing thoughts would be that this is a very pretty, very fun to play game that, although suffers of some really friggin' weird design choices, has a very solid core underneath, with some really cool vehicles and tracks. If you can ignore those, this is money well spent on a very fun racing game. I'd give it an 8/10.

number of helpful: 46 of 93 people (49%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
 A game that potentially could have been truly great, marred by unpolished controls and lousy game mechanics I wish Steam had a neutral rating or sideways thumb because I would have picked that for this game. It's not a bad game but I don't consider it great either. It's a very decent game but with some significant flaws. I chose the thumbs down because I haven't seen any reviews that mention some of the glaring issues I find with this game. This is the most frustrating racer I've ever played in my life. The first major problem is the controls. Each of your vehicles (car, plane, boat) handle differently and they get progressively worse in that exact order. The car handles better than the plane and the plane handles better than the boat (by far).The car handles decently, but could have been tighter. The drifting seems to bug out occasionally.  I'll drift in one direction and then switch directions but my car still goes in the same direction even though I clearly pushed the thumbstick the opposite way. For the most part though it's solid driving. I found the cars to be the most enjoyable part of the game.The plane's controls are looser and more sensitive than the car's which means there's a greater chance of oversteering and flying wildly. I definitely feel less confident in a plane than in a car. But it's nothing compared to the boat, oh my god.The boat controls are absolutely awful. The worst I've experienced in any game. There is like input lag when steering the boat (to make it mimic a real boat I guess) but this inaccuracy makes you constantly over/under steer and it's very easy to go all over the place. After 40 hours of playing this game I still don't have solid control over it and still dread going into the water. I don't know why they made the boating so awkward.  This brings us to the second major problem: the game mechanics. More specifically the physics. When you are driving a car or boat and you get hit in the air by anything -- an opponent's weapon, the terrain, etc.,  your vehicle falls like it's in low gravity  (it also happens when going off a ramp/jump at a very slow speed). You will SLOWLY float down until you hit the ground or water, and depending on how high you are, can take FOREVER. This game has, without a doubt, the worst vehicle recovery time of any racing game I know of. It is not uncommon to take 3, 5, even 10 seconds to regain control because of the low grav or because your vehicle doesn't land properly after getting hit and you can't do anything about it. It really ruins the fast-paced nature of the game. If your boat goes off a ramp at a slow speed you can land in the water upside down and have to slowly wait till it flips upright. Sometimes you will float down on a rock and you can't move and gotta wiggle your way out. Or your car gets popped in the air by an enemy shot while driving uphill and your front wheels won't touch the ground; you are stuck there with your car standing on its rear end and the game doesn't respawn you. It's stupid and makes the game feel broken. Your vehicle should not drop in slow motion, should always land upright, and the game should automatically detect if you're stuck and then respawn you.Furthermore, when your car falls off the side it does not respawn you immediately. Your car has to travel for a certain distance in order for it to trigger the respawn. So if you drive off the edge at a very slow speed, you will slowly fly through the air until you reach that point where it triggers the respawn which can take extra seconds to do. Why they made it like that I don't know. The second you fall off it should trigger the animation so it always takes the same amount of time to respawn. Colliding with other cars is also extremely annoying because there's some wild bouncy physics going on. Simply getting nudged by another car can you send you flying off to the side. Sometimes hitting a car in front of you can make your car bounce backwards like 100 feet and come to a full stop! I've never played a racer where I was afraid to touch the other vehicle. It's something you just expect to do but in this game it can be unpredictable and you will consciously be avoiding contact with other cars. The exception is if you intentionally and forcefully bump them then you can be assured it will send them and not you veering off.The AI is brutal and awful and they will all pile on with attacks and bully you to no end. There is no invincibility after getting attacked like there was in the previous Sonic racer (Sonic and Sega All-Stars) so you can be in 1st place and get hit 5 times in a row and suddenly be last in the blink of an eye.The game's lack of polish is also noticeable by the inability to customize races in multiplayer. You can't change the number of laps. You can't enable or disable weapons or only allow certain types of weapons. At the end of a race the game randomly chooses 3 maps for everyone to vote on instead of letting you choose any map you want and many times one of the choices will be the map you just played. The game will randomly choose mirror track (which I HATE) which is a mirrored layout of the original map and you can't vote against it. There's no ready-up button in the lobby so everyone always has to wait the full minute before the game starts which is annoying. If you join while there's a game in progress you are stuck waiting forever in the lobby till it ends; why couldn't they let you spectate the other players? Or better yet, let you actually join and play and just not count the score to keep it fair. The game and the announcer will also routinely get your finished place wrong. The announcer will say you finished in 1st place when you didn't or the screen will show 1st place when you got 3rd.There's no free driving mode or practice mode in single player which is sorely needed in a game like this. You also can't change your controls in the game. You must exit the game entirely and enter a separate configuration menu.There is zero social interaction with other players. The voice chat is completely broken. All voices come through staticky and garbled whether you're in the lobby or in-game. There is no text chat in lobby or in-game. You might be thinking, who's going to have time to type while racing? You could type before the race starts, after you finish the race, or anytime you feel like it. The point is you should be able to chat in a multiplayer game. At the very least they could have put text chat in the lobby. The inability to communicate at all with other players doesn't make the multiplayer experience feel too different from playing against the AI.You also can't drive the wrong way (unlike the previous game). The second you try you get respawned. Now why would you want to drive the wrong way? Because it's always a fun and cool thing to do in racer games. If you're so far behind there's no chance of you catching up, you could say screw it and drive in the opposite direction to mess with the other players. Not in this game. My apologies for this long essay of a review. I wanted to be thorough in why I think this game is overrated and does not deserve the overwhelmingly positive rating. Because it's simply more frustrating than fun. You'll have tiny moments of enjoyment and the rest of the time you'll be screaming at your monitor wondering why the controls aren't responding the way you want or why it's taking so long to regain control of your vehicle. The game does have some nice levels to race on (and a few aggravating ones), the graphics are reasonably good, the music is catchy, and there's a decent assortment of characters to select. But those things don't make a good racer. It's the controls, mechanics, and gameplay that do. It's a damn shame because this game could have been really great -- a true contender to Mario Kart. But as it is now it feels like a pretty ok game that can be fairly rough around the edges.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												I played the 3DS version of this game for around 56 hours (with everything 100% achieved). While the PC version is reported to be the best one (actually the less worst one), it still shows absurd flaws that should not be present in what is supposed to be an AAA game from an AAA company like Sega. What is shown here is another rushed product.I agree that the essence, the core idea of the game is great and the tracks and mechanics too, but playing the PC version a bit is enough to show you that it's another port from XBox. Sega didn't even bother changing the button indicators, even if you switch the control to keyboard. Additionaly, game configurations are done.. out of the game, in a sepparate application you choose to open when you click the Play button on Steam. Controls, graphics and other configurations are all done in this application. If you want to change something while running the game, forget it. You'll need to close it before doing any other thing. To complete the list of observed problems, the controls configuration doesn't let you configure each sepparate key. Instead, it shows nothing and you have to figure what key does what by yourself.It's a shame for a company like Sega to publish such unfinished, rushed game like this one and if you want to spend your money in it, then go on. You really may like it and may not feel unconfortable with the problems it has, but it's a product I would not recommend to anyone.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												22/25 Gameplay8/10 Fairness8/10 Sound9/10 Graphics6/10 Controls20/20 Multiplayer14/15 Replayability ---87/100The biggest competitor of F1 Race Stars is currently Sonic & All Star Racing Transformed. Who will win the Kart race on PC?In Sonic & All Star Racing Transformed (shorter: SASRT) you are supposed to play single player to unlock more multiplayer. This means that you can play either "Challenges" (similar to usual Singleplayer in F1, but in F1 you do not unlock stuff) to unlock new roads or the campain where you have to win several kinds of races, but have multiple choices if you morely like this or that. But you can also do all. So it is up to you how much you want to play and if you want to choose a way to get a new character. For these you also need "Stars". You collect Stars by winning a race on easy (1 Star), medium (2 Stars) or Hard(3 Stars). Man, I love games with SO MANY UNLOCKS <3So you do not have to make the kinds of races that you do not like. And as their are many types of races (like normal, kill the others, boost, drive trough traffic etc.). But some of them are unfair- for me the traffic one.Another point why I just gave 8 points to "Fairness" is that you need good and powerful power-ups if you lay back in a race. In F1 you have these, not in Sonic though.The Sound is pretty nice, the Characters speak while driving but there is always some kind of childish dubstep which starts annoying after a time. Moreover the Sounds are always kept futuristic and sounds cheap sometimes. The Graphic itself is very good for a 1 year old game, but also: Everything is flashing, the houses next to the road are dancing...well- something for childs but not for me...The biggest lose in the points are the controls. A fun-racer with local split screen (which is awesome on PC) has to be easy to control to make it possible for your friends and family to be good at the game and to understand the controls. My Racing-Expert Friend just did not check how to get Power Start, Rolls, Boosts, Drifting and so on. And I did not check it in the beginning, too (which is not good). When we started playing F1 he instantly checked it all and was in the middle of the field.The Multiplayer is easy to set up and you can just do everything you want, as in F1 Race Stars. So 20/20 here.The game is pretty long, because of the many Singleplayer Stuff and the Multiplayer. It has like 20 hours on Singleplayer (or if you do 100% like...*cough* some *cough* people ;) also 60 hours ) and an active Multiplayer. It would get 15 Points, but I decided to take away one point for the hard Controls.So this is it!TL;DRIf you are looking for a Fun Kart Racer to play with family & friends sometimes - choose F1.If you are looking for a Fun Kart Racer to play Singleplayer or online - choose Sonic.

content:
Posted: January 18
												This is the best kart racer ever released period. Loads of karts, tons of characters to try out, and stages that are truly awesome to play through. Too many highlights to honestly write down in a single review. From Afterburner to Sonic and Panzer to Samba Di Amigo; someone will find something to love here. For me the Afterburner level was truly a great throwback and a beautiful level to boot. Of course, if you played the first Sonic game this one is more of the same, but with a polish not seen before. Land, air, and water racing have been added and they make a huge difference, giving this one a mellifluous fun factor not seen in too many kart games. The graphics have had a substantial update and everything seems like a general improvement to me.The game is compatible with Nvidia AA codes through Inspector, so you can get HBAO and downsampling to work; this is easily the definitive version this way. The consoles, when I played this on PS3, simply cannot compete with 4K and HBAO. The game just looks amazing and at a solid 60FPS too. I give the edge to Transformed versus its prequel, being that it added a wider variety of everything to the mix and the tracks are just insane. There are quite a few challenges like the first game and some secrets to find. The level variety is extremely varied as well. One of the all-time greats in gaming.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												This is the best kart racing game since Mario Kart Double Dash. The graphics, music, controls and overall fan service are all well represented. Driving the boats can be a bit of a pain and there are a few glitches that hinders it from reaching the same level of quality found in Nintendo's Mario Kart series. That aside I would say it's amazingly a lot of fun to play the single player campaign. Mario Kart falls miserably short in comparison in this regard. Also the variety of characters is just mind blowing. The PC version has the most characters available and more are on the way. Keep bringing the content Sega and I'll keep buying.Final verdict: Just buy the damn game! It's way too much fun to pass up!

content:
Posted: February 2
												+ Challenging, skill-based gameplay+ Co-operative multiplayer for all modes; this includes grand prix, and the mission-based campaign, for example (local split-screen or online)- No windowed mode/windowed mode doesn't work- The character models are the worst looking part of this game- Vehicle and environment hitboxes are all over the place- The boat transformation is very clearly the most poorly programmed part of this game- Control inputs will not register randomly- It is unclear what actually counts as a "risk-boost"- Single-race perks/bonuses are tied to a RNG slot machine, instead of a "shop", or "upgrade" system- AI racers will be "balanced" to have the same speed as you. So if you're Sonic, with the "super speed mod" (the ony character with this modification), the AI will still go faster than you in a straight runaway, whether or not they are properly utilizing the boost mechanic- If you are in a online match with nearly empty lobby, the game won't put in bots to fill out the room; there is no option to fix this

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Hands down the best kart racer ever made. If you have ever enjoyed a game in the genre, you need to play this. Beautiful, vibrant, flawlessly balanced (none of that rubber banding or broken power ups like in Mario Kart), great course design, great sound design, great character selection, clever and memorable tracks, native 360 controller support. This is as close to a perfect arcade-style racer as you're ever going to get, and other than the minor annoyance of not being able to adjust graphical settings from within the game (there's a separate configuration program) it's a solid PC port as well.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												On the surface, this looks like a generic Mario Kart rip-off starring lame Sonic characters. Actually play the game and you'll find it's a fast-paced, exacting racer. Despite the name, there are only 6 Sonic characters here. The remaining 20 or so come from all over the place, and some characters aren't even owned by Sega. Characters include Aiai from Super Monkey Ball, Wreck-It Ralph from that cool Disney movie, and the Heavy from Team Fortress 2. The selection available is pretty crazy.The character and stage selection in this game takes a page out of the "Super Smash Bros." playbook: many obscure and retro Sega franchises make great appearences here. This is all on top of an arcade racing game that's much more interesting than recent Mario Kart games.The graphics are great, the transformation gameplay keeps things fresh, and the game is just downright fun to play. I thought the previous Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing game provided some stiff competition to Mario Kart. This one blows Mario Kart out of the water.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I never played the first Sonic Racing so i have no ground to compare this to the first game, but this is truly a fantastic kart racing game. Being an old fan of classic sega i was glad to see the variety of Sega's generally forgotten characters being included in the game, characters from Alex Kidd to people in Crazy Taxi, Shinobi to Shenmue. Just Brilliant. The range of tracks pay homage to old school classics like Golden Axe too!Nostalgia aside, the game plays really well and you really get a feeling of speed that i find is missing from Mario Kart. The drifting and air flips that attribute to your boost really give you incentive to memorize these tracks, tracks of which usually change a lot by the 3rd lap as the area usually destroys dismantles itself by the 3rd lap! This is where the main comparison to Mario Kart comes in...If you love Mario Kart you will proibably like this game and will probably get a lot of fun out of it, if you like the idea of Mario Kart but hate the same old guff and repetitive stuff, you really owe it to yourself to play this. You'll have a lot of fun!(The weapons ain't all that great most of the time, but the actual racing more than makes up for it)

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I never played the first Sonic Racing so i have no ground to compare this to the first game, but this is truly a fantastic kart racing game. Being an old fan of classic sega i was glad to see the variety of Sega's generally forgotten characters being included in the game, characters from Alex Kidd to people in Crazy Taxi, Shinobi to Shenmue. Just Brilliant. The range of tracks pay homage to old school classics like Golden Axe too!Nostalgia aside, the game plays really well and you really get a feeling of speed that i find is missing from Mario Kart. The drifting and air flips that attribute to your boost really give you incentive to memorize these tracks, tracks of which usually change a lot by the 3rd lap as the area usually destroys dismantles itself by the 3rd lap! This is where the main comparison to Mario Kart comes in...If you love Mario Kart you will proibably like this game and will probably get a lot of fun out of it, if you like the idea of Mario Kart but hate the same old guff and repetitive stuff, you really owe it to yourself to play this. You'll have a lot of fun!(The weapons ain't all that great most of the time, but the actual racing more than makes up for it)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												A very nice animated racing game for those who always liked the genre, great tracks, great music, and a nice crew of characters to pick from.The gamplay is easy to pick up for its simplicity, but as you go on playing, you discover there are some tricks to improve the general driving, like doing pirouettes on the air to boost up, finding shortcuts on the tracks, and mastering the items to attack other characters, and for those who seek a challenge, the time trials against developers' "ghosts" are really hard to complete. There's also an online mode where you can play with strangers or with friends, unfortunately, time has rendered online lobbies kinda lonely, and you'll find yourself waiting more than what you are willing to for a race that lasts barely a couple minutes, there's also local mode if you have several controllers.For those long time fans of SEGA, there are many references to previus titles, like Jet Set Radio, Space Channel 5, Wreck-it Ralph (oddly enough) and more; so it doesn't feel like just a re branding of a generic racing game, but as a part of the world this company has created over the years.The music is nice, upbeat and suits the levels, there's an anouncer with a very loud and over the top acting who will inform of the events during the races, it can be turned off for those who find it annoying, and each character has an unique song for their All Stars power, which makes it more enjoyable when you get to do it, and very frightening when you hear another player getting it.Overall, this is a very nice game to play either with friends or alone, it offers casual fun and big challenge as you progress, a perfect gift for a young kid and a completely non-shaming acquisition for a hardcore gamer fan of the genre

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												2fast4meGood graphics, gameplay is pretty much what you'd expect from such an arcade racer. Powerups are either OP or useless (especially true against A or S class AI drivers), but by far the worst (or rather, most frustrating and controller-breaking) part of the game is the difficulty at high levels (especially A class). The entire AI field is against you, which makes the first item pickup feel very bad, time trials are absurdly hard and everything is made to make the game a pain in the butt to finish. Special points for the "secret" S-class difficulty, unlocked after half the game and which makes you go through half the game you've already beaten.Overall an extremely enjoyable game, but finishing it takes ages.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												okay okay... let's start shall we?!First and foremost,lemme warn you: it looks,and it feels like Mario Kart in some aspects, but it is NOT Mario Kart, so if you were looking for a game of luck(and why should you? i may ask)... look somewhere else...This game Rewards Skill over Item usage, and i must say it is a whole much better and different beast for it. you need to know when to drift,where to drift, and pratice. it is easy to go for a small casual playtrough, but hard to master, and i mean it.so, yes, you need to keep your eyes on the road at all times, a thing that i was missiing from today's karting genre... they were predictable at beast, and you could do any turn without releasing the throtle, in this game... you need to brake... (ooooh) and Drift when necessary... and oh boy this game rewards Drift... a LOT.The Cars act like cars instead of Karts, so you gotta keep that in mind... The planes act like planes, and this can trow people off, but for me, that play jet fighter games, is a nice adiction, and boats... well... act like boats, and you can trick on the waves for a little boost on speed if you're good enough... but water drift... for me... is kinda butterish, if you know what i mean...So... with this said...-Pros:-20 Sega characters from lots of games... a great game if you are a Sega Fan...  (i miss Alis from Phantasy Star,but this is just me...)-The vehicles look like vehicles and they are Badass in design, especially the Ryo's Ferrari like car, and of course the Speed star (Sonic's Vehicle)... the ones that look like cars become kinda cartoonish when they transform,but meh... i like the car froms... what can i say... the Planes... i personally like the MIG-21 like fighter jet from the special Team Fortress team...- The tracks are creative and they demand you learn braking points,drifting points, and every corner. it is great for a racing fan like me, that rage like hell, when some games adopt some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mechanic of "not releasing the throtle", so no casual fans... you won't be with your foot stuck on the gas at all times... and this is a better game for it.-An extensive carrer mode,and a painless casual playtrough... for the hardcore fans like me... it can turn into a nightmare goin' for 100%... but well... i cannot complain since i asked for it...-Fun grand prix modes and a very competitive online mode... i was surprised to see the online competition was fiercer than ever...-The car acts like a Car, so no shady mechanics of drift boost while stopped or all that jazz of Mario Kart(Sorry Funky Kong and all the players that love him, but for the love of god, that technique of Stand still drift is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T in my opnion), if you hit something, you will need to accelerate to the max speed again. so this game rewards skill over item usage.-Skill over item usage. this is not a game where you will spam blue shells up and down and all arround, and might i remind you that this mechanic of Mario Kart is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T and what kills that game for me. here, all items serve a propouse and excluding the super star moves that are not harmfull to the first place unless you are fighting for it when you get it (hard,but happens), all are balanced,and needs strategic thinking to use. heck... even the super-star moves aren't game braking, or field equalizers, so yes... you need to have skill to come in first.-Easy to get into. hard to master.Cons:-Boat mechanics are kinda iffy and water drifts are butterish... i don't like it... but this is me...-5 or 6 DLC thingys and tracks... for a game like this i think it should come as unlockables... because well... if i wanna get my friends over to play with me, i want everything on the game so they can enjoy it too... but i digress-the carrer mode is... "too long"... but it is a minor nitpick of mine... again... this is a thing that i asked for... so i digress...-Announcer is  annoying... (and yes i muted him off... sue me... i guess he is homeless now because of *SPOILERS* but i digress)Final Veredict: 8.5/10i had a good time,and the game is fun, with a lot of content. but still, if had potential to be more, so i kinda wished SEGA worked it to its full potential. it had potential to be a 10/10... but the DLC pratice for this kinda of game i cannot accept. and the Boat Butterish mechanics is what kills some water based tracks for me,but it is only me...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												An impressive needle in a haystack of crappy Sonic games, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is truly worthy of competing with other iconic racing games for the title of "The Best One." This game will make you laugh, this game will make you cry, this game will make you rage until there is no tomorrow, but most of all, this game is addicting!Screw all the jazzy intro speech, lets make a pros and cons list:*I didn't bother with Online play, so I can't give an honest review of that feature.Pros:-Graphics are pretty darn good! crisp and clear, water is fluid and reflective, and the sun is even blinding! This is a game that will blow you away visually if you just finished a Mario Kart 64 nostalgia run.-The music is wonderful. There isn't a single track that doesn't make me feel strange, and they all fit very well with the environment. Sound quality for SFX is great too.-Plenty of challenges, and the game kind of evolves with you! Several different modes that will test different skills you didn't think were required to do well in each map, like drifting and boosting, and even knowing when to use a boost in the right moment. It also keeps the gameplay fresh, and you have to option of having a game with or without computers.-Competitive AF. Coms really give you a run for your money in this game. There is no "Easy" way to beat the hardest parts of the game, and that keeps things... interesting to say the least! It also helps you to hone your skills, and learn from your mistakes.-Downloading ghosts allows you to compete with people worldwide without ever needing to battle them directly! This also helps to learn from their driving skills, and improve your skill pool.-Mods allow you to switch things up so you can use your favorite character on more than one track away from their standard stats. They also provide incentive for continued gameplay.-Achievements and stickers give OCD Completionists something to do, increasing gameplay time for much longer.-Stickers and License allow you to show off your achievements online, and can be a testament to your skill.-Plenty of unlockable characters, many whose names echo down the halls of SEGA, and some who are just plain "WTF?" (I'm looking at you Ralph... I still don't understand why you're in this game... not that it matters. I love you.)-Multiplayer option for local fun, just like mario kart seshes.Cons:-Content may seem redundant after a while, mainly I am thinking "Complete the same task on a different course" or "OKAY now beat everything all over again but we'll just increase the difficulty," (this is after you unlock expert mode)-NO TUTORIAL!!! NO DESCRIPTION!!! REEEEEEEEEI had to Google what I couldn't figure out by fiddling with my controller, and there's no clear direction to help you understand the basics. The game literally just throws you in and you learn through experience. I'm still not entirely sure what the All-Star stat does, but my hunch is it determines just how amazing your All-Star ability is.-Hitboxes are irritatingly inconsistent, or just way too large. And this can work for or against you, but for someone like me who likes to drift as close to walls and around corners as I can, it sucks. Item boxes will sometimes be magnetized toward you, and sometimes you have to drive RIGHT down the MIDDLE of it to get the item. Sometimes, you will shoot a rocket or ice and think "I really shouldn't have hit them..." and sometimes Coms will hit you and you will rage "THEY SHOULDN'T HAVE ♥♥♥♥ING HIT ME!!" I have also squeezed my way through various narrows passages in plane mode, and other times I will hit what seems to be an invisible wall. Nothing makes me rage more than invisible walls... just kidding, the next thing is actually worse.-Coms are extremely OP in Expert mode. They have a handicap for all stats, so they will move faster than you, boost faster, they will get all-stars more often, and they seldom mess up on the map.-Coms will almost ALWAYS target you and only you, and in Gran Prix/Battle Race, it will very often feel more like 9vs.1 rather than a free for all. On expert mode, this becomes incredibly frustrating, because it is almost impossible to advance with people hitting you constantly. It forces you to play smart, and sometimes conservatively, or even recklessly... anything to win.-In this game, you ALWAYS start in last place, even in Gran Prix mode, which is kind of a slap in the face for traditional racing games. You ALWAYS have to fight your way to the top, and in no way can you earn a 1st place start.-All of the cons on Coms above lead into the next one: A lot of the time in expert mode, you need to rely on good luck to win, which is kind of a slap in the face to skilled players who truly know what they are doing, but are set up to lose. Even getting an All-Star is not a guaranteed win, and you will have to remain vigilant to hit those stripes first.-Some of the voice acting for this game is just... terrible... I haven't played as every character yet, but Shadow sounds like child with a pitch filter to make him sound lower and more "evil" I suppose.There may be more, but I can't think of anything right now.All in all, this game is like Mario Kart, Diddy Kong Racing, and Sonic Riders all mixed and refined into an amazing and diverse product. I may have listed a lot of cons, which may be intimidating, but I am also very critical, and maybe snotty. I am still having a lot of fun playing this game, as I have a LOT of stickers to earn still, and a lot of Time Trial ghosts to beat, and A LOT of mods to unlock. (Note to others, don't choose to be a completionist... it really sucks.)I'd give this game 8.3 out of 10. It's truly a wonderful experience, and it has it's flaws, but definitely worth the time.
